A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals auras of evocation magic and transmutation magic around the statues, which defy all attempts to move or break them. If a creature attempts to turn the disk manually, the statues discharge lightning that fills the room. All creatures in the room at that moment must make a DC 18 Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 ({@dice 4d10}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Creatures in direct contact with the iron ring or the disk, as well as creatures clad in metal armor, have disadvantage on the saving throw.

entries.name: 22. Arcane Scribblings

entries: {@b Chalkboards}. Mounted on the walls are several blackboards on which arcane phrases and formulas are written in chalk.

{@b Table Trap}. A wooden table in the middle of the room bears a collection of dusty flasks and beakers. The table is draped in cobwebs and obviously hasn't been disturbed in a long time. The paraphernalia is meant to distract viewers from the polymorph trap upon which the table rests (see "{@area Polymorph Traps|700|x}").

The chalk scribblings were left by one of {@creature Arcturia|WDMM}'s failed apprentices. Any character who studies the markings and succeeds on a DC 16 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check can tell that they are attempts by one individual to unravel the secrets of spells beyond their comprehension. Spellcasters who have the {@spell disintegrate} and {@spell flesh to stone} spells on their spell lists can tell that those are the spells being researched, though neither spell can be learned from these incomplete scribblings.
Sounds of battle in this room can be heard by the hobgoblin guards in {@area area 25|74e|x}, who investigate if alerted. (They approach from the east.)

entries.name: 23. Experiments
entries: The doors to these rooms have {@spell arcane lock} spells cast on them that allow {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} alone to pass. A door can be forced open with a successful DC 25 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: 23a. Shoe Hulk
entries: Lying in the middle of this room is an old shoe with a {@creature scorpion} hiding in it. If the shoe is disturbed, the scorpion scuttles out and attacks the nearest creature.

The scorpion is, in fact, an {@creature umber hulk} under the effect of a {@spell polymorph} spell made permanent with a {@spell wish} spell. The umber hulk reverts to its true form and attacks when its scorpion form is reduced to 0 hit points.

entries.name: 23b. Bad Blades
entries: A corroded steel helm rests atop a pile of rusty swords in the middle of the room. When another creature enters the room, the pile of swords gathers into a vaguely humanoid form with the helm surmounting it and attacks. This assemblage of rusty steel has the statistics of {@creature animated armor}, except that its attacks deal piercing damage instead of bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: 23c. Rodent of Unusual Size

entries: {@b Monster}. A giant two-headed rat (use {@creature death dog} statistics) is trapped here. This rodent is the size of a human and is hostile toward all intruders.
{@b Meat Chute}. In the ceiling near the north wall is a rectangular opening, 12 inches long by 6 inches wide, that forms the mouth of a stone chute leading up.

Every few hours, a brick of rotting meat slides down the chute from a hidden chamber above. The meat hits the floor with a wet smack and is promptly eaten by the monstrous rodent. A Tiny or gaseous creature can access this small, hidden chamber by climbing up the chute. There are no exits from the upper room, which contains only hundreds of bricks of pink, rotting meat and a magical mechanism that pushes them down the chute at random intervals. It's impossible to discern what sort of creature the meat has been harvested from.

entries.name: 23d. Guffaw the Stone Eater
entries: This room contains the smashed remains of a dwarf statue and a plump {@creature deep gnome (svirfneblin)} named Guffaw Gravelstock, who was plucked from his Underdark gem mine by {@creature Arcturia|WDMM}. He is unfamiliar with Undermountain.

{@creature Arcturia|WDMM}'s magic has given the gnome an insatiable appetite for carved stone. He uses his war pick to break up the statue and is devouring it slowly, one piece at a time. He can't keep himself from stopping to eat any carved stone he sees—and there's no end to how much he can consume. He begs to be left alone so he can finish his meal in peace. A successful {@spell dispel magic} spell (DC 19) cast on Guffaw rids him of his unique magical malady.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The instant he is cured of his malady, Guffaw coughs up two diamonds (5,000 gp each). He is just as surprised to see the gemstones as anyone else, and he offers them to the characters as a reward for "saving" him. He then seeks out a way back to the Underdark, wanting nothing more to do with Undermountain.
{@b Chalkboard}. A blackboard covers the entire east wall. Written across it in big chalk letters are the words "YOU ALL FAIL!" in Common.

{@b Desks}. Whenever a creature enters the room, seven stone desks magically rise from the floor, facing the blackboard in an arc. (The desks sink back into the floor when all creatures leave the room.)
{@b Secret Door}. A secret door in the south wall pushes open to reveal a dusty, web-choked passage between this room and {@area area 25|74e|x}.
{@b Guards}. Two {@creature Hobgoblin||hobgoblins} stand guard here, one in front of each door. They attack intruders, ganging up on one enemy at a time.
{@b Arch}. A stone arch embedded in the middle of the east wall has an image of an open book carved into its keystone.
{@b Secret Door}. A secret door in the north wall opens into a dusty, web-choked passage between this room and {@area area 24|74c|x}.

entries.name: Arch Gate to Level 9
entries: The arch is one of Halaster's magic gates (see "Gates"). Its rules are as follows:

items: Если держать открытую книгу в пределах 5 футов от арки, ворота открываются на 1 минуту. Книга превращается в пыль, когда врата открываются, даже если это книга заклинаний.

Чтобы пройти через эти ворота, персонаж должен быть 10-го уровня или выше (см. "{@area Jhesiyra Kestellharp|016|x}"). Первое существо, прошедшее через ворота, вызывает руну старейшины (см. "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}").
A creature that passes through the gate appears in {@area area 49 on level 9|4e3|x}, in the closest unoccupied space next to the identical gate located there.

entries.name: 26. Apprentice's Quarters
entries: Like her former master Halaster, {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} takes on apprentices of her own from time to time, but they seldom survive for long. This room contains a moldy quilt draped over a stone bier against the north wall and a wooden desk with a high-backed chair in the southeast corner. On one corner of the desk rests a yellowed human skull topped with a half-melted wax candle.

entries.name: 27. Dead Apprentice

entries: {@b Quilt}. A moldy quilt is draped over a stone bier against the south wall.
{@b Desk}. A wooden desk stands in the northeast corner. Slumped in a high-backed chair behind the desk is a human skeleton clad in perforated black robes.

The inanimate skeleton belongs to a human apprentice named Kazvark, whom {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} killed with a barrage of magic missiles for failing to complete a simple homework assignment. {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} destroyed Kazvark's spellbook but didn't check his pockets for valuables.

entries.name: Mithral Key
entries: Characters who search the apprentice's robes find a 6-inch-long, flat piece of mithral shaped like a U in one pocket. This key is one of six required to activate the weapon of mass disintegration in {@area area 37|76e|x}.

entries.name: 28. Specimens
entries: Characters who listen at either door to this room hear strange clicking noises from beyond.
{@b Hook Horror}. A {@creature hook horror} is trapped in the room, but there's more to it than meets the eye.
{@b Shelves}. The curved walls are lined with stone shelves.
{@b Smashed Jars}. Hundreds of jars of body parts lie smashed on the floor.

A hobgoblin accidentally set off a polymorph trap and was transformed into this hook horror. The other hobgoblins decided to trap it in this room as a joke. Lacking hands, the hook horror couldn't open the doors to escape, and it swept the bottles off the shelves in a rage, spilling their contents.

When the hook horror drops to 0 hit points, it turns back into an {@condition unconscious} {@creature hobgoblin} named Jarrk. Despite his recent misadventure, Jarrk is fanatically loyal to Doomcrown and would never willingly betray him.

{@creature Arcturia|WDMM} collected body parts from all sorts of Underdark specimens. Characters who search through the detritus find moth wings, beetle shells, darkmantle eyes, stirge hooks, flumph tendrils, troglodyte claws, demon ichor, gelatinous residue, and other worthless creepy bits. At your discretion, some useful spell components might lie amid the refuse.

entries.name: 29. Laboratory

entries: {@b Vanar Freth}. A {@creature drow mage} named Vanar Freth and his summoned {@creature shadow demon} companion are quietly searching the room when the characters arrive.
{@b Statues}. Standing in opposite corners are two 9-foot-tall statues of ogres transforming into giant flies.

{@b Table}. A large stone table stands in the middle of the room. Several curious items rest atop it, including a black cube-shaped box on a folded gray blanket, and the slimy, decapitated head of a mind flayer whose headless body has bled out on the floor nearby. The corpse is being feasted on by maggots.
{@b Old Trap}. The double door to the southwest and the floor around it are scorched by fire—the result of a trap set off long ago.

The drow mage has managed to get this far without being detected. Left to his own devices, he eventually finds the treasure hidden under the table (see "Treasure" below). The shadow demon watches for trouble while the drow busies himself with the search.

Vanar fights to keep any treasure he has found but otherwise avoids hostilities. Once his search of Arcturiadoom is complete, he plans to return to the House Freth fortress on {@adventure level 12|WDMM|12} and report to his master, {@creature Drivvin Freth|WDMM}.

entries.name: Table
entries: Until recently, {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} had a mind flayer assistant. She tore off its head to study the psychic energy stored in its brain. Next to the head is a long pair of steel tweezers and a ladle.

The 1-foot black cube is an ebony-framed box fitted with panes of black glass. The box has a hinged lid and radiates an aura of transmutation magic under the scrutiny of a {@spell detect magic} spell. When a Tiny beast small enough to fit in the box (such as a rat or a lizard) is placed inside and the lid is closed tightly, the box magically transforms it into some other Tiny beast (your choice) unless it succeeds on a DC 15 Wisdom saving throw. The box can do this eight more times before its magic is fully spent, whereupon it crumbles to sand.

The folded gray blanket upon which the box rests is, in fact, the carefully removed skin of a doppelganger. Other items on the table include a jar of cockatrice tongues, a block of soft clay (the material component for the {@spell stone shape} spell) wrapped in moist cloth, and a wooden coffer labeled "Polymorph" containing a dozen caterpillar cocoons (material components for the {@spell polymorph} spell).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Hidden in the floor under the table is a small secret compartment that can be discovered with a successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. It contains a jade circlet worth 1,500 gp (the material component for a {@spell shapechange} spell) and a {@item spell scroll} of {@spell polymorph}.

entries.name: 30. Hideous Transmutation

entries: {@b Carrion Ogre}. Lying on the floor in the middle of the room, held down with chains, is a creature that has the body of an ogre and the head of a carrion crawler.
{@b Body Parts}. The ogre's severed head and the carrion crawler's decapitated body lie discarded in the northern corner of the room, where they have begun to putrefy and emit a dreadful stench.
{@b Key Ring}. Hanging from a stone peg on the northwest wall is an iron ring with three keys.

The creature chained to the floor is alive, having survived a ghastly magical ritual that can't be reversed or undone. It is malnourished and must feed on carrion to survive. The chains around it are looped through iron rings bolted to the floor and secured with three heavy padlocks, which can be unlocked with the keys hanging on the wall. If released, the creature rushes over to the rotting remains of its former bodies and begins devouring them.
The creature is an {@creature ogre}, with these changes:

items: While lashed to the floor, the creature is {@condition prone} and {@condition restrained}. It also suffers from two levels of {@condition exhaustion}.
It has an Intelligence of 1, and it can't speak or understand any language.
Replace the ogre's action options with the following action options.

entries.name: Multiattack
entries: The creature makes two attacks: one with its tentacles and one with its bite.

entries.name: Tentacles
entries: {@i Melee Weapon Attack}: +8 to hit, reach 10 ft., one creature. {@i Hit}: 4 ({@dice 1d4 + 2}) poison damage, and the target must succeed on a DC 13 Constitution saving throw or be {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute. Until this poison ends, the target is {@condition paralyzed}. The target can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the poison on itself on a success.

entries.name: Bite
entries: {@i Melee Weapon Attack}: +4 to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@i Hit}: 7 ({@dice 2d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

entries.name: 31. Illithid's Assistant
entries: This room was reserved for {@creature Arcturia|WDMM}'s mind flayer assistant, which met a grisly end in {@area area 29|757|x}. It has the following features:
{@b Decor}. The stone walls are sculpted to resemble tentacles entwining around and through bleached human skulls embedded in the stone.
{@b Slime Pool}. In the middle of the floor is a shallow oval pool filled with dark, foul-smelling slime. (The slime has a soothing effect on mind flayers but no magical properties to speak of.)
{@b Assistant}. Standing in the eastern corner of the room, facing the corner, is a male human wearing nothing but a leather harness and a loincloth.

The harness-wearing human is Ellix Gaspar (NE male Tethyrian human {@creature mage} with no spells prepared). He holds a half-eaten loaf of bread. {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} pulled him out of Dweomercore ({@adventure level 9|WDMM|9}) a few months ago to serve as her assistant, only to find him too obnoxious to bear. She cast a {@spell feeblemind} spell on him and gave him to her mind flayer assistant, who promptly forced him to don new apparel befitting his station.

In his current state, Ellix is vacant-eyed and barely responsive, with a tendency to trip over his own feet and drool uncontrollably. He has a tenday left before he can attempt another saving throw to end the {@spell feeblemind} effect. If he regains his senses, he smartly tries to flee Undermountain with the last shreds of his sanity and dignity. He doesn't know what happened to his spellbook ({@creature Arcturia|WDMM} hid it in {@area area 40b|780|x}), but once his faculties return, he recalls the layout of this level and how to return to the surface.

entries.name: 32. Death's Head Barracks
entries: Hobgoblin forces are quartered in these rooms, which are engulfed in a permanent antimagic field similar to that created by an {@spell antimagic field} spell (the result of a magical experiment gone awry).

entries.name: 32a. Soldiers' Quarters
entries: Thirty {@creature Hobgoblin||hobgoblins} rest in wooden bunk beds stacked three tiers high. There are enough beds to accommodate sixty guards. The hobgoblins sleep in their armor; their weapons and shields hang from hooks on the corners of their bunks.

entries.name: 32b. Guard Post
entries: Four {@creature Hobgoblin||hobgoblins} stand guard here—two flanking the door to {@area area 32a|764|x}, and two flanking the door to area 32c. Any battle here brings reinforcements from those areas, as well as from {@area area 20|740|x}.

entries.name: 32c. Captains' Quarters
entries: Two {@creature Hobgoblin Captain||hobgoblin captains} converse quietly in this room, which contains three beds. Other furnishings include a stone table surrounded by six wooden stools, with an unlit iron chandelier suspended above it.

The captains are worried about the recent abnormal behavior of their warlord commander (see area 33) and contemplating what to do about it. So far, the captains have hidden Doomcrown's bizarre preoccupations from the rest of the hobgoblin legion and remain, for the time being, loyal subordinates.

entries.name: 33. Doomcrown's Quarters
entries: {@b Monsters}. If he hasn't been drawn elsewhere, Doomcrown the {@creature hobgoblin warlord} is here, attended by a {@creature flumph} that speaks to him telepathically.
{@b Underdark Model}. Standing about the room are six 7-foot-tall, stalagmite-shaped spires made of tiny rectangular blocks, with a half-finished seventh tower under construction.

{@b Furnishings}. Furnishings include a wooden bed, an overstuffed leather chair with a matching ottoman, a stone shelf holding a wooden cask of ale, a handsomely carved stone table strewn with mason's tools and bits of stone, and a heavy wooden seafarer's trunk with a smashed lock.
{@b Tapestry}. On the south wall hangs an old, faded tapestry that depicts a beautiful crystal cavern.

A few days after settling in Arcturiadoom, the hobgoblin warlord commanded his underlings to bring him a set of mason's tools. Some old tools were gathered and promptly delivered to him. In the days since, Doomcrown has been carving rectangular blocks of stone (each 2 inches wide, 4 inches long, and 1 inch thick) and using them to build odd, tower-like structures resembling stalagmites. The endeavor has helped alleviate his boredom, even if he doesn't know exactly why he's building them. The answer lies with his strange companion.

Until recently, this flumph surreptitiously fed on the mental energy of {@creature Arcturia|WDMM}'s mind flayer assistant. The illithid's sudden death (see {@area area 29|757|x}) cut off the flumph's food supply. Fortunately, it can get by for some time without needing to feed on more psionic energy. It shacked up with Doomcrown and has been trying to convince him to reform. The hobgoblin has proven to be stubbornly, irredeemably evil, but their lengthy telepathic contact has caused Doomcrown to exhibit odd traits, including a subconscious need to recreate the flumph's home—the Underdark—out of building blocks. The flumph knows that its longing to return home is affecting the hobgoblin's behavior, but it relies on Doomcrown for protection. If the two become separated, the flumph opts to return to the Underdark.

The characters can befriend the flumph and coax it into joining the party for a while. It has encountered adventurers in Undermountain before and is generally quite fond of them and their tales of the surface world.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The wooden trunk contains the hobgoblins' loot: 2,500 gp, an electrum pepper shaker (25 gp), a pewter candlestick (25 gp), a red velvet cape (50 gp), an ornate coral statuette of a ship cresting a wave (250 gp), a dwarven beard comb made of lapis lazuli and set with gemstones (750 gp), a platinum crown with black pearl inlay (2,500 gp), and an elven helm made of leafed gold with a spiral horn of amethyst protruding from its brow (7,500 gp).

entries.name: 34. Shrieking Gas Spore
entries: Floating in the middle of this otherwise empty room is a {@creature gas spore} that has the added defense of a shrieker. When bright light or a creature comes within 30 feet of the gas spore, it uses its reaction to emit a shriek audible within 300 feet of it. The gas spore continues to shriek until the disturbance moves out of range and for {@dice 1d4} rounds afterward.
The shrieking of the gas spore alerts the hobgoblins in {@area areas 32c|766|x} and {@area 33|767}, who come to investigate.

entries.name: 35. Rallying Hall
entries: This wide hall has a 50-foot-high ceiling that angles down to 20 feet high as it travels north and east. Shouts echo from area 36, the door to which is slightly open.

entries.name: 36. Death's Head Training
entries: The door to this room hangs ajar, and shouts in Goblin come from within. The room contains the following features:

{@b Hobgoblins}. Twelve {@creature Hobgoblin||hobgoblins} are practicing phalanx formation maneuvers in the middle of the room, overseen by a {@creature hobgoblin captain}. When faced with an unknown threat, the hobgoblins close ranks and attack.
{@b Furnishings}. Around the perimeter of the room are wooden trestle tables and benches.

{@b Wall Decor}. The room is lit by {@spell continual flame} spells cast on iron torch sconces bolted to the walls. Mounted on stone plaques between the sconces are the heads of three dwarves, two orogs, a troglodyte, and a gargoyle.

entries.name: 37. Weapon of Mass Disintegration
entries: In the event that her experiments got out of hand or her enemies tracked her down, {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} built this chamber to purge them all at once while protecting herself and her apprentices (of which she currently has none). The chamber has the following features:

{@b Plated Walls}. At the end of a short hallway is a 20-foot-high domed chamber with seven narrow alcoves. Every surface is covered with gleaming mithral plates. Each alcove is brightly lit by the yellow glow of a small crystal dome embedded in its 8-foot-high ceiling.
{@b Key Shapes}. Set into the mithral-plated walls between the alcoves are six key-shaped indentations at chest height. Each indentation is 6 inches long.

Each alcove is 8 feet tall and 4 feet deep, and narrows in width from 3 feet to 1 foot. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals a strong aura of abjuration magic engulfing each alcove, which is just spacious enough to accommodate a single Medium creature. The crystal dome in the ceiling is the source of the alcove's magic, and destroying its globe renders an alcove dark and powerless. Each dome has AC 11, a damage threshold of 10, 1 hit point, and immunity to acid, fire, poison, and psychic damage.

entries.name: Using the Mithral Keys
entries: Six mithral keys are required to activate the chamber. Each conforms in shape to one of the six indentations in the walls, which are (from left to right, going clockwise around the room): an upside-down Y, a backward J with a small loop at the top, an upside-down F, an upside-down U, a V with a small loop at the bottom, and an H missing its top left stem. When the six keys (located in {@area areas 7|716|x}, {@area 10|71e}, {@area 13b|72b}, {@area 27|752}, and {@area 39a|776}) are placed in their corresponding indentations, a {@spell magic mouth} spell counts down from 20 seconds (in Common). At the end of the countdown, there is an ear-splitting whine, and a powerful spell deals 150 force damage to every creature on level 14 of Undermountain (no saving throw allowed). Any creature reduced to 0 hit points by this effect is immediately disintegrated and reduced to a pile of dust. The spell also disintegrates the six mithral keys.

Creatures that are standing in the lit alcoves when the spell goes off are unharmed, as are creatures inside an antimagic field. (The antimagic fields in {@area areas 4|710|x} and {@area 32|763} protect the creatures there.)

entries.name: 38. Guest Quarters
entries: {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} keeps this room for special guests, such as Halaster or visiting wizards who have magic to trade. Its features are as follows:

{@b Furnishings}. A large canopied bed dominates the eastern alcove. At the foot of the bed rests a large iron chest with a flat lid and clawed feet. An owlbear rug is splayed across the floor in front of the chest and the bed.
{@b Alcove}. A black curtain conceals an alcove to the southwest. In front of the curtain is an overstuffed leather chair and a small table with a crystal decanter.

The alcove contains a stone statue that lacks fine features, resembling a blank-faced humanoid. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of transmutation magic around the statue, which alters its form to mimic the appearance of any Small or Medium humanoid that touches it. The statue has no other properties.

entries.name: Trapped Chest
entries: The chest has an iron key in its lock, and turning the key unlocks it. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of transmutation magic emanating from inside the chest.

The chest is empty except for a magic mirror fastened to the inside of its lid. Any creature that sees its reflection in the mirror is targeted by a {@spell flesh to stone} spell (save DC 20). Once the spell has been triggered, the mirror ceases to be magical.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The crystal decanter is worth 250 gp but is fragile. It contains cheap wine. The owlbear rug is worth 75 gp.

entries.name: 39. Arcturia's Boudoirs
entries: Mounted above the double door to these chambers is a 4-foot-diameter, 2-inch-thick disk of black stone upon which is engraved a white symbol depicting a bony human hand. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals a powerful aura of abjuration magic around the seal.
The seal has AC 17, 30 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. If the seal is destroyed, the rakshasa bound to these chambers can escape.

entries.name: 39a. Gold and Black Boudoir

entries: {@b Light}. The walls and ceiling are painted gold. Mounted to them are black iron sconces with {@spell continual flame} spells cast on them. These fires cast the entire room in bright, flickering light.
{@b Carpet and Cushions}. Thick, wall-to-wall carpeting with alternating gold and black zigzagging patterns covers the floor, with a few soft, gold silk cushions strewn about.

{@b Hammocks}. Two tasseled hammocks are stretched between four black pillars near the east wall. Napping in one of them is a beautiful young man wearing gold sandals and a golden silk skirt. (The man is Alussiarr, a {@creature rakshasa} using a {@spell disguise self} spell to mask its true form.)
{@b Braziers}. Two braziers made of carved black basalt rest in the middle of the floor. Smoldering blocks of incense in each brazier fill the room with a pungent but pleasant aroma.

The rakshasa is bound to these boudoirs and can't travel beyond {@area area 39|775|x}, even through the use of spells, as long as the circular seal above the doors remains in place. (Spells that would transport the rakshasa away from the area simply fail.) {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} trapped the rakshasa here years ago and draws blood from the fiend to fuel her terrible transmutation rituals.

Alussiarr has no beef with the adventurers and doesn't want to distress them by revealing its true form. It does, however, ask them to set it free by breaking the seal outside the room. If the characters do so, the rakshasa turns {@condition invisible} and makes its way out of Undermountain with the goal of working all manner of evil in Waterdeep—but not before telling the heroes where they can find {@creature Arcturia|WDMM}'s spellbook ({@area area 40b|780|x}) and phylactery ({@area area 40c|783|x}), as well as the command word to reveal the bookshelves in {@area area 40b|780|x}. It also gives them a flat, 6-inch-long mithral key shaped like a Y, and tells them it's one of six keys required to activate the weapon of mass disintegration in {@area area 37|76e|x}. Alussiarr doesn't know where the other five keys are kept.

If the characters haggle with the rakshasa, it also vows to provide up to three additional pieces of useful information in exchange for its freedom, such as the way to {@adventure level 15|WDMM|15}. If the characters refuse to help Alussiarr, the rakshasa shrugs its shoulders, returns to its nap, and gives them nothing in return. It has waited years to escape—it can wait a few more.
{@b Mosaics}. Gruesome mosaics made from humanoid bones decorate stone-framed panels set into the walls.
{@b Furnishings}. Arrayed about the room are six divans made of stitched flesh stretched over bone frames and a table made entirely of glued teeth and fangs.
{@b Arch}. Set into the middle of the south wall is a stone arch. Carved into its keystone are three human-like stick figures holding hands.

entries.name: Arch Gate to Level 17
entries: Арка является одними из магических ворот Халастера (см. "{@area Gates|028|x}"). Правила ее использования следующие:

items: If three humanoids hold hands while standing within 5 feet of the gate, it opens for 1 minute.

Characters must be 14th level or higher to pass through this gate (see "{@area Jhesiyra Kestellharp|016|x}"). The first creature to pass through the gate triggers an elder rune (see "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}").
A creature that passes through the gate appears in {@area area 11 on level 17|8c8|x}, in the closest unoccupied space next to the identical gate located there.

entries.name: 39c. Crystalight Boudoir

entries: {@b Chandeliers}. Four crystal chandeliers hang from the ceiling, bathing the chamber in magical light.

{@b Harpsichord}. A {@creature living unseen servant|WDMM} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) plays a harpsichord in the southeast corner. Because the unseen servant is {@condition invisible}, the harpsichord seems to be playing by itself.
{@b Dancers}. Waltzing about the room are a resplendently dressed man and woman. The man wears a gold ruffled shirt and blue trousers, while the woman wears a ruffled blue ball gown and a gold tiara.
The living unseen servant plays the harpsichord tirelessly and fights only in self-defense.

A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals auras of transmutation magic around the dancers who, in truth, are a mated pair of {@creature Young Blue Dragon||young blue dragons}. The dragons are {@creature Arcturia|WDMM}'s guests, and their names are Nystalancer and Venasorrn. With the help of {@creature Arcturia|WDMM}'s magic, they are experiencing what it's like to be human and pay no attention to new arrivals. If the music stops or either of them is touched or harmed by another creature, the dragons revert to their true forms simultaneously and attack. Their clothing and jewelry merge into their new forms. Arcturiadoom is not their lair, and they keep no treasure here.

entries.name: 40. Arcturia's Chambers
entries: {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} has cleared out an old dwarven crypt and turned it into her private sanctum.

entries.name: 40a. Sentinel Statue

entries: {@b Statue}. Standing in the middle of this 30-foot-high room is a life-size statue of a dwarf in plate armor, wearing a bucket helm and standing at attention atop a block of stone that measures 3 feet on a side.
{@b Secret Door}. Set into the north wall is a secret door that swings open into area 40b.

The dwarf statue is inseparable from its base, and its base is inseparable from the floor. If anyone other than {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} opens the secret door, the statue transforms into a 6-inch-thick wall of stone that bisects the room from east to west, creating separate chambers to the north and south. The wall is permanent. Each 10-foot-square section of it has AC 15, 180 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage.

entries.name: 40b. Arcturia's Library

entries: {@b Pedestal}. A 5-foot-tall stone pedestal carved in the likeness of a nalfeshnee demon stands near the southern wall.
{@b Secret Door and Trap}. A secret door in the east wall opens into area 40c. The 10-foot-square space in front of the secret door contains a polymorph trap (see "{@area Polymorph Traps|700|x}").
A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals auras of transmutation magic around the pedestal and rectangular sections of the north wall where hidden bookshelves magically emerge (see "Treasure" below).

The pedestal is a Small object with AC 15, 20 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. Under certain conditions, it transforms into a {@creature nalfeshnee} (see area 40c). The pedestal also transforms if it takes damage. With Halaster's help, {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} pressed the demon into service. Its primary task is to guard the lich's phylactery. While in pedestal form, the demon is unaffected by the weapon of mass disintegration in {@area area 37|76e|x}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: When the proper command word is spoken ("palimpsest"), tall stone bookshelves magically protrude from the north wall. The shelves are inaccessible otherwise. Packed into these shelves are dozens of spellbooks that {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} has accumulated over the years. They contain most of the wizard spells in the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}, plus any others of your choosing.

All the 8th-level and 9th-level spells that can be found are contained in {@creature Arcturia|WDMM}'s personal spellbook, which magically changes its appearance each dawn. When first discovered, it has black crystal covers and gold-leaf pages engraved with arcane runes and phrases. The book is titled {@i Arcturia's Arcane Esoterica: Vol. IX}, and it contains the following spells: {@spell antimagic field}, {@spell astral projection}, {@spell dominate monster}, {@spell feeblemind}, {@spell gate}, {@spell incendiary cloud}, {@spell power word kill}, {@spell power word stun}, {@spell shapechange}, {@spell telepathy}, {@spell true polymorph}, and {@spell wish}.

entries.name: 40c. Arcturia's Phylactery
entries: A niche in the north wall holds a small box made of purple crystal—{@creature Arcturia|WDMM}'s phylactery. The phylactery does not detect as magical. If the characters remove the phylactery from this room, the demonic pedestal in {@area area 40b|780|x} transforms into a {@creature nalfeshnee} and attacks them.

Destroying this phylactery leaves {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} with no means to rejuvenate once her physical form is destroyed. The object can be destroyed only after being digested in the stomach of a mimic for three days. A {@spell legend lore} spell or similar magic reveals the exact method of the phylactery's destruction.

entries.name: 41. Watchful Pillars
entries: Two stone pillars, each carved with dozens of lidless eyes facing in all directions, flank a double door.
The doors swing inward, revealing a 10-foot-wide landing at the top of a staircase that descends hundreds of feet to {@area level 15, area 1|791|x}.

entries.name: Aftermath
entries: {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} returns to her home periodically to peruse her spellbooks, place new polymorph traps throughout the level, and alter the conditions that trigger existing ones, as needed. If intruders have laid waste to her defenses, she might forge an alliance with the mind flayers on {@area level 17|735|x}, intending to secure an illithid security force to further strengthen her hold on this level. If the dragons in {@area area 39c|77b|x} are still alive, {@creature Arcturia|WDMM} bribes them into guarding the tunnels leading to {@adventure levels 13|WDMM|13} and {@adventure 15|WDMM|15}.

Defeating {@creature Emberosa|WDMM} and her giants stalls the progress on Mecha-Halaster, but only until Halaster finds new metalsmiths (perhaps a band of azers) to continue the work. The Mad Mage considers the hobgoblins expendable.

data.name: Level 15: Obstacle Course
entries: The Obstacle Course is designed for four 13th-level characters, and adventurers who defeat the monsters on this level should gain enough XP to advance to 14th level. Before running this level of Undermountain, review the description of the death tyrant in the "Beholders" entry in the {@book Monster Manual|MM}, as that information will help you roleplay the death tyrant that claims the Obstacle Course as its lair.

entries.name: What Dwells Here?
entries: Visitors to this level must contend with mechanical traps left behind by the Melairkyn dwarves, magical traps crafted by the Mad Mage, and an undead beholder named Netherskull. They might also encounter nuisances from the Elemental Planes of Earth and Fire, and a band of githzerai on a special mission.

entries.name: Netherskull the Death Tyrant
entries: Many years ago, a beholder floated up from the Underdark and infiltrated Undermountain. After carving out a lair for itself, the beholder dreamed itself into undeath, becoming a death tyrant called Netherskull.

When Halaster and Netherskull met in battle, the wizard emerged triumphant, but he couldn't bring himself to destroy such a formidable dungeon guardian. Instead, Halaster agreed to let Netherskull remain the undisputed lord of this level on the condition that it permit Halaster to tinker with and maintain the level's traps, as well as add a magical, mean-spirited announcer that taunts visitors as they blunder from one room to another (see "{@area Halaster's Play-by-Play|78d|x}").

entries.name: Githzerai Zerths
entries: Four githzerai zerths have taken refuge in the Obstacle Course. They use their psychic abilities and natural stealth to hide from Halaster's magical gaze and the death tyrant's watchful eyes.

The githzerai are aware that githyanki have conquered the Crystal Labyrinth ({@adventure level 16|WDMM|16}) and are waging war against a mind flayer colony in Seadeeps ({@adventure level 17|WDMM|17}). The githzerai wait patiently to see the outcome of the Seadeeps conflict but stand ready to assist should the githyanki need help. The leader of this githzerai band, Yrlakka, is a member of the Sha'sal Khou, a faction of renegade githyanki and githzerai who seek to reunify the gith races. By helping the githyanki defeat a common foe, Yrlakka hopes to demonstrate the merits of a single unified gith race—not only to the evil githyanki, but also to the younger githzerai zerths who follow him. Yrlakka is concerned because his most headstrong pupil, a githzerai named Ezria, has disappeared. He fears (correctly) that Ezria was captured by the githyanki on {@adventure level 16|WDMM|16} while trying to find weak spots in their defenses.

entries.name: Lava Children and Friends
entries: Several lava children (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) brought to Undermountain by Halaster's apprentice {@creature Trobriand|WDMM} have migrated from {@adventure level 13|WDMM|13} to the Obstacle Course and taken residence around a lava-filled chasm in the heart of the level, joining the magma mephits that dwell there. Netherskull terrorizes the lava children and magma mephits from time to time, but not enough to force them to leave the warmth of the chasm. The evil mephits trick or goad the lava children into attacking all other creatures that blunder into their territory.

entries.name: Traps
entries: The Obstacle Course is replete with mechanical and magical traps. Two recurring types are described below.

entries.name: Covered Pits
entries: Melairkyn dwarves built these pits, and Halaster keeps them in working order.

A 10-foot-square slab of 2-inch-thick stone covers each pit. Each cover is carved to resemble the floor surrounding the pit. A character who has a passive Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) score of 17 or higher recognizes the trapped section of floor as the cover of a pit. A character can also search the floor for traps, detecting the pit with a successful DC 17 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. Once a pit is detected, an iron spike or similar object can be wedged between the pit's cover and the surrounding floor to prevent the cover from opening. The cover can also be held in place using an {@spell arcane lock} spell or similar magic.

When a weight of 25 pounds or more is placed on the cover, it swings downward (as long as it hasn't been prevented from opening) and remains open until Halaster happens by and decides to close it. Any creature or object on the cover when it swings open falls into the pit below. The pit's depth and other hazards vary by location, as described in the location's description. Regardless of a pit's depth, its walls are too smooth for characters to climb without the aid of climbing gear, magic, or the Spider Climb trait (or a similar ability).

entries.name: Teleport Traps
entries: Teleport traps are at the locations marked T on the map. A teleport trap is a magical effect usually cast on a 10-foot-square section of floor, set to trigger whenever a creature enters the trap's space. The trap extends all the way to the ceiling of the space that contains it.

A teleport trap is {@condition invisible} to the senses, and a permanent {@spell Nystul's magic aura} spell prevents divination spells such as {@spell detect magic} from revealing the trap's presence. A successful {@spell dispel magic} spell (DC 18) cast on the trapped section of floor destroys the trap.

A creature that enters the trap's space is teleported along with any objects it is wearing or carrying to another teleport trap (or the nearest unoccupied space). There is no saving throw to resist the teleportation effect, and the destination varies from trap to trap. Once a creature has been teleported in this way, it is unaffected by teleport traps on this level for 1 hour.

When a creature is teleported by a trap, Halaster's booming voice shouts "Teleported!" in Common. The magical voice originates at the point of departure and the point of arrival, and it is audible in both locations out to a range of 100 feet.
Some teleport traps have additional effects, as described in their encounter locations.

entries.name: Splitting the Party
entries: Teleport traps are designed to split the party—a situation that can challenge any DM. To ensure that every member of a split party gets attention, think of yourself as a film editor cutting scenes in a movie. Jump from one group of characters to the next while spending no more than a few minutes with any given group or individual. Tense moments are great times to "cut" from one group to another—don't be afraid to leave them hanging!

entries.name: Halaster's Play-By-Play
entries: Whenever a creature makes an attack roll, takes damage, or performs a death-defying stunt in the Obstacle Course, Halaster's disembodied voice magically chimes in with play-by-play commentary. The effect can't be dispelled, and its exact point of origin can't be ascertained. The play-by-play can be silenced for good by destroying the source in {@area area 30b|7f8|x} or by defeating the death tyrant Netherskull. Improvise the play-by-play as you see fit. The commentary tends to be sarcastic, biting, and demoralizing. A few examples of what the disembodied voice might say are provided below:

items: {@b When a character misses with a melee attack roll}: "Swing and a miss!"
{@b When a character misses with a ranged attack roll}: "Missed that one by a mile!"
{@b When a character takes damage}: "Ouch, that'll leave a mark!"
{@b When the characters kill a monster}: "Score one for the underdogs!"
{@b When the party cleric drops to 0 hit points}: "The cleric is down! Stick a fork in it—this party's done!"

entries.name: Exploring This Level
entries: The following encounter locations are keyed to map 15. The most distinguishing feature of the level is a gaping chasm that borders several dungeon corridors and chambers (see {@area area 40|818|x} for details).
The Obstacle Course is mostly devoid of furnishings, since the level was designed explicitly to dispose of intruders in an efficient yet entertaining manner.

entries.name: 1. On Your Mark! Get Set! Go!
entries: A broad set of stairs descend to a large chamber with the following features:

{@b Pillars}. Four stone pillars support a 35-foot-high, vaulted ceiling strung with cobwebs. When one or more humanoids approach within 30 feet of the northeast pillar, a {@spell magic mouth} spell activates, forming a stone mouth on the pillar.

{@b Statues}. Tunnel exits to the north and south are flanked by 12-foot-tall stone statues of {@creature Halaster Blackcloak|WDMM}, depicted as a bearded, scowling old wizard wearing a robe covered with lidless eyes and clutching a stout scepter with a red dragon's head at each end.
{@b Mine Carts}. Two mine carts made of corroded iron stand near a tunnel exit in the east wall.

entries.name: Halaster Statues
entries: These statues can't be moved, knocked over, or damaged in any way. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of transmutation magic around each one.
Any nonmagical weapon that strikes a statue for the purpose of dealing damage to it turns to dust.

entries.name: Magic Mouth
entries: In Halaster's voice, the magic mouth speaks the following words in Common before disappearing: "Welcome to the Obstacle Course! Place all weapons and magic items in the carts for safekeeping. You won't need them. Hurry! Time is running out."

entries.name: Mine Carts
entries: The axles, wheels, and brake handles of the mine carts are rusted in place. A {@spell prestidigitation} cantrip or similar magic can free the mechanisms and render a mine cart functional for the spell's duration, but it still squeals loudly when rolled across the floor.

The characters are under no compulsion to heed Halaster's {@spell magic mouth} spell. Any items they place in the carts and leave there are safe for 24 hours. After that, all unattended objects in the carts disappear—taken by Halaster to {@area area 5 on level 23|b23|x}. Characters can find the missing items waiting for them there.

entries.name: Covered Pit
entries: This 40-foot-deep hidden pit (see "{@area Covered Pits|78c|x}") is located between the two northernmost statues. Halaster has cast a {@spell glyph of warding} spell at the bottom of the pit, set to trigger a {@spell fireball} spell (save DC 22) when a creature lands on the pit floor. The fireball is created using a 7th-level spell slot, engulfs all creatures in the pit, and deals 42 ({@dice 12d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Creatures in the pit have disadvantage on the saving throw, as there's precious little space to maneuver.

entries.name: Teleport Trap
entries: Halaster has placed a teleport trap (see "{@area Teleport Traps|78d|x}") between the two southern statues. A creature teleported by this trap arrives at a location determined by rolling a {@dice d20} and consulting the following table:

entries.name: Additional Effect: Elder Rune
entries: The first time a creature triggers this teleport trap, an elder rune (see "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}") appears in the air between the two southern statues a split second after the creature disappears, and at the same moment a booming voice shouts, "Teleported!" Draw a card from the Elder Runes Deck (see {@adventure appendix B|WDMM|26}) to determine which rune appears. This rune targets all creatures within 60 feet of it with the same effect (bane or boon, determined randomly).

entries.name: 2. Clacking Floor
entries: The stones that comprise the floor of this 10-foot-high chamber make clacking noises when stepped on—a crude but effective alarm system installed by dwarves long ago. A character who searches the floor for traps before stepping on it discovers the hidden alarm system with a successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check.
A secret door in the west wall opens into {@area area 3|79b|x}, and north of the room is a hidden pit trap.

entries.name: Covered Pit
entries: This hidden pit (see "{@area Covered Pits|78c|x}") is 20 feet deep, but the bottom 10 feet is occupied by a {@creature gelatinous cube}. Any creature that falls into the pit takes 10 ({@dice 3d6}) acid damage as it sinks into the cube and is automatically engulfed by it. If the cube is attacked from above, it rises out of the pit on its turn and tries to engulf anything in its path.

entries.name: 3. Stuffed Monsters
entries: The secret doors leading to this chamber are 10 feet square. It takes a singular or combined Strength of 16 to push open each door. The room is choked with dust and cobwebs. Five dead creatures stuffed with sawdust and displayed in lifelike poses are crammed into the northern half of the room. The stuffed monsters and their weights are summarized below:

items: An aarakocra with wings spread, clutching a javelin (120 pounds)
A reared-up ankheg (600 pounds)
A young brass dragon with wings tucked in, head lowered, and jaws agape (750 pounds)
An ettercap with its arms raised menacingly (200 pounds)
A hell hound with a {@spell continual flame} spell cast in its gullet (150 pounds)

entries.name: 4. Caught in the Tentacles

entries: {@b Ceilings}. The central portion of this chamber has a domed ceiling 20 feet high. Wings to the east and west have 15-foot-high arched ceilings.

{@b Crevasse}. Orange light and intense heat spill from a crevasse that splits the room nearly in two. (The source of the light is a river of lava 30 feet below, which widens toward the southeast, originating in {@area area 40d|81c|x}.)
{@b Statues}. Two life-size iron statues of mind flayers sit in opposite corners of the central chamber, facing one another with their tentacles outstretched.

Halaster placed the mind flayer statues here and trapped them. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals auras of abjuration and evocation magic around each one. It doesn't require an ability check to realize that a humanoid head would fit nicely inside each mind flayer's tentacles.

Any humanoid that passes between the statues must succeed on a DC 22 Intelligence saving throw or be {@condition charmed} by the statues for 1 minute. The {@condition charmed} creature must use all of its movement on its turn to move toward the nearest statue and stick its head between the tentacles. (A Small humanoid must climb the front of the statue to do so.) Only one creature at a time can place its head between the tentacles. A humanoid that places its head between the tentacles is no longer {@condition charmed} but is {@condition stunned} and remains so until another creature separates it from the statue or until the statue is destroyed.
Each statue is rooted to the floor and is a Medium object with AC 19, 40 hit points, and immunity to all damage except force damage.

entries.name: 5. Antechamber
entries: Several traps and obstacles await visitors to these areas. The ceilings are 10 feet high throughout.

entries.name: 5a. Halaster's Coin

entries: {@b Columns}. Six 10-foot-wide columns support the ceiling.
{@b Gilded Statue}. An alcove in the south wall contains a gilded statue of {@creature Halaster Blackcloak|WDMM} holding what looks like coins in its outstretched right hand.
{@b Secret Door}. A northwest alcove contains a secret door that opens into {@area area 5d|7a3|x}.

The statue holds five gold-painted stone coins in its outstretched hand. Close inspection reveals that one of the coins is loose and can be removed from the statue's hand. Engraved on each side of the loose coin is Halaster's rune. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of abjuration magic around the coin, and an {@spell identify} spell or similar magic reveals its magical property.

When an elder rune triggers within 60 feet of the creature that possesses the coin, the creature can use its reaction and the coin to change the elder rune's bane effect into a boon effect, or vice versa. After the coin is used once, it disappears in a flash, accompanied by Halaster's booming laugh.

entries.name: 5b. Teleport Trap
entries: This trap is located in the far west alcove in the south wall (see "{@area Teleport Traps|78d|x}"). A creature teleported by this trap arrives at a location determined by rolling a {@dice d20} and consulting the following table:

entries.name: 5c. Electrified Portcullises
entries: This empty, 30-foot-wide, 10-foot-deep, 10-foot-high chamber is closed off by two humming iron portcullises with 3-inch gaps between their 1-inch-thick bars. A winch on the north wall of the chamber raises and lowers both portcullises simultaneously, but it's beyond the reach of characters standing outside the room. A {@spell mage hand} cantrip or an {@spell unseen servant} spell cannot exert enough force to turn the winch, but a {@spell telekinesis} spell does. A character can also circumvent one or both portcullises using a spell such as {@spell misty step} or {@spell gaseous form}. Any creature that touches either portcullis or passes between its electrified bars takes 22 ({@dice 4d10}) lightning damage, or 44 ({@dice 8d10}) lightning damage if the creature is made of ferrous metal or wearing metal armor.

entries.name: 5d. Deep Duerra's Den
entries: This chamber, hidden behind a secret door, is choked with dust and cobwebs. The room's only feature is a 9-foot-tall stone statue of a cloaked female dwarf, her face half hidden under a cowl. In one outstretched hand, she holds an alien skull, yellowed with age.

The statue depicts Deep Duerra, the duergar god of conquest and psionics. Recognizing this sinister figure requires a successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check; dwarves (including duergar) have advantage on the check. A successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana} or {@skill Nature}) check confirms that she is holding the skull of a long-dead mind flayer.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of illusion magic around the mind flayer skull, and an {@spell identify} spell or similar magic reveals its magical properties. A creature with the skull in its possession is {@condition invisible} to mind flayers, as is anything the creature is wearing or carrying. The skull crumbles to dust and is destroyed {@dice 1d10} days after leaving the statue's grasp.
{@b Scorch Marks}. This circular chamber has a 20-foot-high domed ceiling. Every surface is scorched and covered with soot, in a manner suggesting that multiple fiery explosions have occurred here.

{@b Xunderbrok}. On a section of the back wall, an exclamation is scrawled in the soot: XUNDERBROK! (A previous explorer spelled this word on the wall. For information on its meaning, see {@area area 39c on level 6|3a6|x}.)
{@b Chest}. A stone chest also blackened by soot lies open in the middle of the floor. (The stone chest is empty, its contents looted long ago. It weighs 500 pounds.)

entries.name: Teleport Trap
entries: In addition to the empty chest, the middle 10-foot square of the room contains a teleport trap (see "{@area Teleport Traps|78d|x}"). A creature teleported by this trap arrives at a location determined by rolling a {@dice d20} and consulting the following table:

entries.name: 7. Fidelio's Folly

entries: {@b Chasm}. This partially destroyed room is dimly lit by the lava at the bottom of the nearby chasm (see {@area area 40|818|x}). Past the chasm's ledge is a spectral bridge that connects two other partially destroyed chambers (see {@area area 16|7c4|x}).
{@b Peeling Paint}. The vibrant green paint that once adorned the walls has mostly peeled off from the chasm's extreme heat.

{@b Ghost}. As one or more characters attempt to cross the room, the {@creature ghost} of {@creature Fidelio|WDMM}, a human paladin of Tyr, appears in the middle of the room. The air around it reeks of cheap cologne.

{@creature Fidelio|WDMM}'s ghost has 80 hit points and appears as a translucent knight in shining armor, with the symbol of Tyr (a set of balanced scales) on his ghostly breastplate. The ghost is lawful good and speaks in Common. If the ghost is reduced to 0 hit points, it re-forms 24 hours later in a random location within the Obstacle Course and remains there until encountered again.

Over a century ago, {@creature Fidelio|WDMM} began his campaign to single-handedly rid Undermountain of evil, foolishly believing that Tyr would not let him perish. The arrogant paladin fought his way down to the Obstacle Course, only to be disintegrated unceremoniously by Netherskull. {@creature Fidelio|WDMM}'s convictions are so strong, however, that his spirit cannot rest until it defeats Netherskull in battle. The ghost has confronted the death tyrant many times on its own, but these battles are always short-lived, ending with Netherskull destroying the ghost and causing it to re-form elsewhere in the dungeon.

{@creature Fidelio|WDMM}'s ghost is looking for a potential host who is willing to be possessed by it. A character who allows the possession forgoes the saving throw to resist the effect, and you can allow the player to continue running the character. While possessed, the character gains the following flaw, which supersedes any conflicting personality trait: "I, {@creature Fidelio|WDMM}, favored son of Tyr, must strike down Netherskull at all costs, as justice demands." The character also reeks of cheap cologne while possessed.

His arrogance aside, {@creature Fidelio|WDMM} won't possess a humanoid without its consent. If it can't find a willing host, it offers to join the party on two conditions: the characters must seek out Netherskull with haste, combat it, and allow {@creature Fidelio|WDMM} to deal the death blow to it. The ghost knows the location of the death tyrant's lair ({@area area 39c|816|x}) but doesn't know how to open the doors that lead to it, or about the secret way in ({@area area 39b|815|x}).

If Netherskull is reduced to 0 hit points by a creature other than {@creature Fidelio|WDMM}'s ghost or its host, the paladin of Tyr can't accept that someone other than he dealt the killing blow. The ghost wallows in despair, doomed to haunt the Obstacle Course until another follower of Tyr convinces it to move on with a successful DC 20 Charisma ({@skill Persuasion}) check. A non-follower can attempt the check, but only by posing as a Tyr worshiper and fooling the ghost with a successful DC 10 Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check.

If it succeeds in reducing Netherskull to 0 hit points, either as a ghost or when in possession of a host, {@creature Fidelio|WDMM}'s ghost is laid to rest. "Victory at last!" says the ghost as it fades away. Afterward, Tyr bestows a {@i blessing of protection} (see "{@book Supernatural Gifts|DMG|7|Supernatural Gifts}" in chapter 7 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}) on any character who served as {@creature Fidelio|WDMM}'s host.
For laying {@creature Fidelio|WDMM}'s spirit to rest, the characters should receive XP as if they had defeated the ghost in combat.

entries.name: 8. Teleport Trap
entries: This unadorned hallway contains a teleport trap (see "{@area Teleport Traps|78d|x}"). A creature teleported by this trap arrives at a location determined by rolling a {@dice d20} and consulting the following table:

entries.name: 9. Hidden Rune
entries: This 20-foot-high chamber shows signs of past extravagance. It has the following features:
{@b Chasm}. The floor to the north gives way to a chasm and a hot, bubbling pool of lava 30 feet below. Intense heat from the lava fills this room.

{@b Bridge}. A 10-foot-wide spectral bridge—nothing more than a flat plane of wispy, magical force—extends across the chasm from this room to another ledge 120 feet away. (For more information on the bridge, see {@area area 16|7c4|x}. The far ledge is described in {@area area 17|7c6|x}.)
{@b Double Door}. At the south end of the room, two pillars carved with scores of eyes flank a stone double door engraved with a giant letter H.

If their handles are tugged, the double doors fly open, revealing a stone wall with a giant elder rune carved into it (see "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}"). Draw a card from the Elder Runes Deck (see {@adventure appendix B|WDMM|26}) to determine which rune waits beyond the doors. This rune targets all creatures in the room with the same effect (bane or boon, determined randomly). If Halaster's personal rune is indicated, an additional effect occurs: the pillars flanking the doorway shoot multicolored rays from their eyes, and each creature in the room becomes the target of a {@spell prismatic spray} spell (save DC 22). Once this effect is resolved, the elder rune on the wall disappears, and the doors slam shut unless they are held open or otherwise prevented from closing.
When the doors close, the trap resets so that the next time the doors open, another randomly determined elder rune appears on the wall behind them.

entries.name: 10. Roller-Dragon
entries: This oval chamber has a 10-foot-high ceiling. Standing against the east wall is a stone statue of a young gold dragon on stone rollers. The dragon's mouth is agape, teeth bared, and its wings are folded in tight.

entries.name: Dragon Statue
entries: The statue, which weighs 5 tons, can move forward or backward on its stone rollers. It moves on its own when the teleport trap triggers (see "Teleport Trap" below) but otherwise remains still. While the statue is still, its rollers are locked to prevent the statue from being moved.
The rolling statue is designed to fit snugly in the dungeon's 10-foot-wide passageways. It is a Large object with AC 17, 120 hit points, and immunity to all damage except force damage.

entries.name: Teleport Trap
entries: A teleport trap fills the 10-foot-square space in front of the west exit. A creature teleported by this trap arrives at a location determined by rolling a {@dice d20} and consulting the following table:

entries.name: Additional Effect: Rolling Dragon
entries: When a creature is teleported to this location from another teleport trap, a disembodied voice shouts, "Teleported!" at the same moment the 10-foot-wide dragon statue rolls forward 60 feet, passing through the teleport trap's space and slamming into the wall of the corridor that leads west. Any creature in the path of the rolling statue, including the one teleported by the trap, must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw to get out of its way. On a failed save, the creature is struck by the rolling statue, falls {@condition prone}, and takes 55 ({@dice 10d10}) bludgeoning damage.
The statue returns to its original position against the east wall after 1 minute, ready to roll again the next time a creature teleports into the room.

entries.name: 11. Dead End

entries: {@b Teleport Trap}. A teleport trap (see "{@area Teleport Traps|78d|x}") is situated near the bend in the corridor.
{@b Corpse}. A dead drow lies on the floor at the end of the tunnel, around the corner from the teleport trap.

The rotting corpse of a drow mage lies slumped against a wall at the end of the tunnel, his face frozen in a scream, his black robe torn and dusty. The drow, Elvilac Zmirth, was killed by Netherskull's remote Death Ray (one of the death tyrant's regional effects) after finishing a long rest in this dead-end tunnel. His sister, Lorlynn, can be found in {@area area 14b|7be|x}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Characters who search Elvilac's remains find a zurkhwood wand (used as an arcane focus), a spellbook with black leather covers, and a spider silk pouch containing three soft purple mushrooms that give off an aura when subjected to a {@spell detect magic} spell or similar magic. Elvilac's spellbook contains all the spells he had prepared (see the {@creature drow mage} stat block), plus {@spell dispel magic}, {@spell stoneskin}, and {@spell telekinesis}. Each of the purple mushrooms can be eaten as an action and has the magical properties of a {@item potion of greater healing}.

entries.name: Teleport Trap
entries: A teleport trap fills the 10-foot-square space marked on map 15. A creature teleported by this trap arrives at a location determined by rolling a {@dice d20} and consulting the following table:

entries.name: 12. Wheel Room
entries: Hidden behind a secret door is a dusty, 10-foot-high room that contains the following features:
{@b Lever}. In the middle of the room, a 6-foot-diameter rusty iron wheel protrudes from the floor.
{@b Unseen Servant}. Standing silently in the northwest corner is a {@creature living unseen servant|WDMM} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}).

The rusty iron wheel can be rotated a half turn in either direction, squealing loudly until it clicks to a stop. Turning the wheel causes mechanisms under the floor to clank and whir, locking the lids of all the covered pits on this level and deactivating all the teleport traps on this level. Resetting the wheel to its original position reactivates these traps.

The living unseen servant doesn't announce its presence to anyone. If the characters turn the wheel but fail to destroy the unseen servant, it waits until they leave the room before using the wheel to reactivate the traps on this level.

entries.name: 13. Hidden Traps
entries: Two traps are hidden in these unadorned halls.

entries.name: 13a. Teleport Trap
entries: A teleport trap (see "{@area Teleport Traps|78d|x}") fills the 10-foot-square space marked on the map. A creature teleported by this trap arrives at a location determined by rolling a {@dice d20} and consulting the following table:

entries.name: Additional Effect: Summoned Devil
entries: After a creature triggers the trap and is teleported away, an {@creature ice devil} appears in the trap's space and attacks any other creatures it sees at the same moment a booming voice shouts, "Teleported!" The devil doesn't trigger any of the teleport traps on this level. It disappears when reduced to 0 hit points or after 1 minute. Each time the trap is triggered, a new ice devil appears.

entries.name: 13b. Covered Pit
entries: This hidden pit (see "{@area Covered Pits|78c|x}") is 40 feet deep, and a creature that falls the distance takes 14 ({@dice 4d6}) bludgeoning damage. In addition, Halaster has cast a {@spell glyph of warding} spell at the bottom of the pit, set to trigger a {@spell cloudkill} spell (save DC 22) when a creature lands on the floor of the pit. The poisonous fog created by the spell fills the pit and lasts for 10 minutes. The spell is cast using an 8th-level spell slot. It deals 36 ({@dice 8d8}) poison damage on a failed saving throw, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: 14. Sepulchers
entries: This corner of the dungeon holds a pair of dusty crypts.

entries.name: 14a. Southern Crypt
entries: The door to this room is engraved with a large rune, while the door frame is carved with leering dwarven skulls. A character who understands Dwarvish recognizes the rune on the door as a dwarven symbol of death (identical to the one in {@area area 27|7e7|x}).
Behind the door is a dusty, 10-foot-high crypt that contains the following features:
{@b Sarcophagi}. Three open stone sarcophagi rest in the middle of the crypt, their lids lying in pieces on the floor.
{@b Skeletons}. Piled against the back wall are scores of moldering dwarf skeletons (inanimate and harmless).

A pair of drow mages and siblings named Elvilac and Lorlynn searched and plundered the sarcophagi. Each sarcophagus rests atop a 1-foot-tall stone bier and is 7 feet long, 3 feet wide, and 3 feet tall. The contents of the sarcophagi are as follows:

items: The northern sarcophagus contains the moldy bones of a dwarf with corroded bits of armor clinging to it. Its skull is hidden inside a rusty bucket helm.
The middle sarcophagus is empty, but a body-shaped impression in the dust suggests that someone rested here recently. (Elvilac, the dead drow in area 11, rested here while he meditated.)
The southern sarcophagus contains the bones and tattered robe of a long-dead mind flayer.

entries.name: 14b. Northern Crypt
entries: The door to this room is identical to the one guarding {@area area 14a|7bc|x}, except for a triangular hole at the bottom. Behind the door is a dusty, 10-foot-high crypt containing the following features:
{@b Skeletons and Sarcophagi}. Twelve dwarf {@creature Skeleton||skeletons} mill aimlessly around three unmarked stone sarcophagi in the middle of this crypt.
{@b Lorlynn}. The southern sarcophagus is missing its lid. A female {@creature drow mage} named Lorlynn Zmirth rests inside. She sits up when intruders enter the crypt.

Lorlynn came to Undermountain with her twin brother Elvilac in hopes of finding useful spellbooks and magic. Netherskull has chosen to leave her alone for the time being. Her brother wasn't so fortunate (see {@area area 11|7b1|x}). Lorlynn doesn't know he's dead and is expecting him to return any moment, but news of his death doesn't upset her. So gloomy a creature was he that if Lorlynn can recover and animate his corpse, it will be as though he never died.

Lorlynn wears a tattered gray spider silk robe and cowl that, coupled with her gaunt features, makes her appear distinctly banshee-like. She abhors the company of other humanoids except her brother. She is in a relaxing trance when the characters first arrive. Normally indifferent toward adventurers, she turns hostile if she finds that the characters have her brother's spellbook and refuse to surrender it to her. If her skeletons are turned or destroyed and she is reduced to half her hit points or fewer, Lorlynn offers information in exchange for her life. She knows one random Undermountain secret, determined by drawing a card from the Secrets Deck (see {@adventure appendix C|WDMM|27}). She also knows how to deactivate the pit traps and teleport traps on this level using the wheel in {@area area 12|7b5|x}, but knows nothing of the living unseen servant that Halaster recently put there.

Each sarcophagus sits atop a 1-foot-tall stone bier and is 7 feet long, 3 feet wide, and 3 feet tall. A character with a Strength score of 15 or higher can push off the lid of a sarcophagus easily. The contents of each sarcophagus are described below:

items: The northern sarcophagus has a gaping crack in one of its sides, and four harmless rats have used this crack to creep inside and make a nest among the moldering bones of a sahuagin (placed here by Halaster to confound grave robbers). Lifting the lid or tapping on the sarcophagus causes {@dice 1d4} rats to emerge in a panic. The detritus in the nest includes two random trinkets, determined by rolling on the {@item Trinket|phb|Trinkets} table in chapter 5 of the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}.
The middle sarcophagus is full of cobwebs, hidden under which is a right-handed iron gauntlet with six fingers. Characters can use the gauntlet to activate the gate in {@area area 24c|7dc|x}.

The southern sarcophagus (Lorlynn's bed) has a secret compartment in the bottom that can be found with a successful DC 20 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. Its contents are described in "Treasure" below.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Lorlynn wears a black gold ring set with bloodstones (250 gp) on the index finger of her right hand and carries a bone wand (her arcane focus), a pouch containing two bone dice (1 gp each), and a bloodstained sackcloth doll with two jet eyes (100 gp per eye).

The secret compartment in Lorlynn's sarcophagus holds her spellbook, which has covers made of stitched elf flesh. It contains all the spells she has prepared plus {@spell animate dead}, {@spell arcane eye}, and {@spell wall of stone}.

{@b Chasm}. The air is hot and dry. A crumbling ledge overlooks a great chasm brightly lit by a bubbling pool of lava 30 feet below. Visible from this location is a spectral bridge that spans the chasm (see {@area area 16|7c4|x}).
{@b Debris}. What's left of the floor is strewn with broken, corroded fragments of dwarf-sized chain mail and plate armor.
{@b Arch}. Embedded in the middle of the south wall is a stone arch made up of one hundred stone jigsaw pieces. This arch is one of Halaster's magic gates (see "{@area Gates|028|x}").

entries.name: Arch Gate to Level 20
entries: Each of the arch's one hundred jigsaw pieces weighs 10 pounds. The rules of this gate are as follows:

items: Only one piece of the arch can be removed at any given time. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals that one of the pieces (determined randomly) is magical. When that piece is removed from the arch, it disappears, and the gate opens for 1 minute. When the gate closes, the piece removed from the arch magically reappears in its proper place, and a different piece becomes magical and must be removed to reopen the gate.

If a wrong piece is removed from the arch, an {@creature adult white dragon} magically appears in an unoccupied space within 60 feet of the arch and attacks any creature it can see. The dragon disappears when it is slain or after 1 minute. When the dragon disappears, the piece that was removed from the arch magically reappears in its previous place.

Characters must be at least 16th level or higher to pass through this gate (see "{@area Jhesiyra Kestellharp|016|x}"). The first creature to pass through the gate triggers an elder rune (see "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}").
A creature that passes through the gate appears in {@area area 9b on level 20|9ff|x}, in the closest unoccupied space next to the identical gate located there.

entries.name: 16. Spectral Bridge
entries: A 120-foot-long, 10-foot-wide bridge of wispy magical energy spans the lava-filled chasm, connecting areas 9 and 17. This bridge provides a relatively safe means of crossing the chasm, particularly given that the chasm suppresses {@spell fly} spells and similar magic (see {@area area 40|818|x}).

The bridge, suspended 30 feet above the surface of the lava, is flat, translucent, and without railings. Normally, it is solid and safe to walk on—but any section of the bridge within 10 feet of a magic item becomes insubstantial. A creature or object passes through an insubstantial section of the bridge like it's not there. A successful {@spell dispel magic} spell cast on the bridge (DC 18) causes the entire span to disappear for 1 hour.

In order to retain their magic items as they cross the bridge, the characters must devise a way to distance the items from the bridge as they cross it, such as by tying the items to ropes and dangling them more than 10 feet from the span.

entries.name: Fireball Trap
entries: Whenever a creature on the bridge crosses the midpoint of the span, there is a {@chance 25|25 percent} chance that the lava pool below spouts a fireball that explodes at a point centered on that creature. The effect is that of a {@spell fireball} spell (save DC 19) cast using a 7th-level spell slot. It deals 42 ({@dice 12d6}) fire damage on a failed saving throw, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: 17. Ruined Chamber
entries: What's left of this room is perched above the lava at the north end of the spectral bridge ({@area area 16|7c4|x}). Most of the chamber was destroyed when the chasm was created, but the following features remain:
{@b Frescoes}. Damaged frescoes cling to the few walls that weren't destroyed by the chasm's formation. These frescoes depict obscene orgies between drow and demons.
{@b Door Carving}. Covering the north door (to {@area area 18|7c8|x}) is a silver-inlaid carving of a spider's web.

entries.name: 18. Ruined Shrine
entries: This room stands empty except for fist-sized bas-reliefs of spiders at various heights along the walls. The furnishings of the shrine were either destroyed by the formation of the chasm or disintegrated by the death tyrant. What remains is an empty chamber with a crumbling ledge that overlooks a lava pool 30 feet below.

Characters who make no effort to conceal themselves as they approach the ledge are spotted by the creatures frolicking in {@area area 40d|81c|x}: six {@creature Lava Child|WDMM|lava children} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) and seven {@creature Magma Mephit||magma mephits}. See {@area area 40d|81c|x} for details.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A character who searches the north wall and succeeds on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check discovers that one of the spider carvings on that wall can be detached. The carving is 6 feet off the floor, weighs 10 pounds, and acts as a plug sealing a stone tube. Removing the plug causes 250 pp to cascade out of the tube onto the floor.

entries.name: 19. Grabby Pillars

entries: {@b Ropers}. Three {@creature Roper||ropers} are disguised as 10-foot-tall pillars of rough-hewn stone that extend from floor to ceiling. Lying on the floor between the pillars is a key of bone. Set into each pillar at a height of 7 feet is a lidded eye fixed on the key. (These are the ropers' actual eyes, which appear still and lifeless.)
{@b Frescoes}. The walls are covered with faded frescoes that depict Underdark caverns and fungi forests.
{@b Teleport Trap}. A teleport trap (see "{@area Teleport Traps|78d|x}") fills the space marked on the map.

The 6-inch-long key is carved from a dragon's finger bone, and its yellow head is shaped like an H. This key unlocks the doors to {@area area 39c|816|x}. A similar key can be found in {@area area 30b|7f8|x}.

The ropers remain still and hold their pillar-like shapes until the key is disturbed or until one or more of the ropers is attacked or poked in the eye, whereupon all three sprout tendrils and attack all other creatures in the room. The ropers ignore intruders otherwise, since Halaster keeps them well fed.

entries.name: Teleport Trap
entries: A creature teleported by this room's teleport trap arrives at a location determined by rolling a {@dice d20} and consulting the following table:

entries.name: 20. Separated Hall
entries: This empty hallway has been broken away from the rest of the level by the lava-filled chasm (described in area 40). Creatures in the hall can hear the lava children playing in {@area area 40b|81a|x} to the north.

entries.name: 21. Destroyed Room
entries: A crumbling ledge overlooks a great chasm brightly lit by a bubbling pool of lava 30 feet below. Characters who peer over the ledge can see several creatures frolicking in the lava.

Characters who make no effort to conceal themselves as they cross the room are detected and attacked by the creatures frolicking in the pool: six {@creature Lava Child|WDMM|lava children} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) and seven {@creature Magma Mephit||magma mephits}. See {@area area 40d|81c|x} for details.

entries.name: 22. Teleport Traps
entries: These tunnels contain two teleport traps (see "{@area Teleport Traps|78d|x}").

entries.name: 22a. West Teleport Trap
entries: A creature teleported by this trap arrives at a location determined by rolling a {@dice d20} and consulting the following table:

entries.name: Additional Effect: Vergadain Lives
entries: When a creature is teleported by this trap, a disembodied voice shouts, "Teleported!" at the same moment the {@creature stone golem} in {@area area 23|7d3|x} animates. This golem begins stalking through nearby tunnels, attacking all other creatures it sees. If it finds nothing to attack after prowling these tunnels for 10 minutes, it returns to its alcove and goes dormant.

entries.name: 22b. East Teleport Trap
entries: A creature teleported by this trap arrives at a location determined by rolling a {@dice d20} and consulting the following table:

entries.name: 23. Statue of Vergadain
entries: A 9-foot-tall {@creature stone golem} carved in the likeness of Vergadain, the dwarven god of luck and wealth, stands in this alcove with shoulders squared and a smug look carved into its face. Dwarves immediately recognize Vergadain's likeness, while other characters can determine its identity with a successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check. Its eyes are glittering black sapphires that can't be pried loose until the golem is destroyed (see "Treasure" below).
The golem remains motionless until it is attacked or activated by the trap in {@area area 22a|7d0|x}. It has the following additional trait:

entries.name: Magic Theft
