entries: As a bonus action, the golem targets one creature it can see within 30 feet of it. The target must succeed on a DC 17 Charisma saving throw, or all magic items in its possession are teleported to the bottom of the pit in {@area area 31|7fa|x}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The two black sapphires embedded in the golem's eyes are worth 5,000 gp each.

entries.name: 24. Githzerai Retreat
entries: Four githzerai have taken refuge in this corner of the Obstacle Course (see "{@area Githzerai Zerths|789|x}"). Using psionics, they hide themselves from the scrying eyes of Halaster. They also avoid Netherskull.

The githzerai leader, Yrlakka, is a father figure to the others and serves as their mentor. They attack mind flayers and their thralls on sight, but all other creatures are treated with cautious respect until they prove themselves undeserving of such consideration.
All rooms and corridors in this part of the dungeon have flat, 10-foot-high ceilings.

entries.name: 24a. Hall of Smiths

entries: {@b Decor}. Painted stone tiles of dwarf smiths at work once covered the walls, but most have cracked and fallen to the floor, where they lie in small heaps of swept-up rubble.
{@b Scuff Marks}. Scuff marks on the floor show evidence of stone furnishings long since removed.
Characters who hold bright light sources in this room or make a lot of noise alert the githzerai in {@area area 24c|7dc|x}, who remain where they are but can't be surprised.

entries.name: Teleport Trap
entries: This trap fills a 10-foot-square section of the passage leading to {@area area 24d|7e0|x}. A creature teleported by this trap arrives at a location determined by rolling a {@dice d20} and consulting the following table:
Since they can't avoid the trap, the githzerai steer clear of {@area area 24d|7e0|x} and the hallway that leads to it unless they need to use the trap to escape a greater danger.

entries.name: 24b. Resting Chamber
entries: The githzerai use this chamber to sleep and meditate. Five bedrolls are laid out on the dusty floor, one for each githzerai (including the missing zerth).

entries.name: 24c. Zerths
entries: The door to this room is ajar. Characters who approach stealthily might overhear the githzerai speaking quietly inside. The room's features are as follows:

{@b Githzerai}. Four {@creature Githzerai Zerth||githzerai zerths} are having a hushed conversation in the middle of the room, speaking Gith. They stop talking and ready themselves for combat if they detect intruders.
{@b Arch}. A stone arch is embedded in the middle of the south wall. Carved into the arch's keystone is an image of a six-fingered gauntlet.

The zerths include Yrlakka, the group's leader, and three of his pupils: two female githzerai named Azal and Vond, and a male named Rishindar. Yrlakka's primary concern is the safe return of his missing pupil, Ezria, who he believes was captured while scouting the githyanki forces on {@adventure level 16|WDMM|16}. If the characters agree to find Ezria, Yrlakka and his remaining pupils tag along unless the characters would rather complete the quest by themselves. If Ezria is rescued and reunited with his companions, Yrlakka rewards the characters with the wand in his possession (see "Treasure" below).

If the characters aren't interested in aiding the githzerai but request help getting through the Obstacle Course, Yrlakka tells them that the level is rigged with many traps and guarded by a death tyrant.

entries.name: Arch Gate to Level 17
entries: The arch is one of Halaster's magical gates (see "{@area Gates|028|x}"). This gate's rules are as follows:

items: The gate opens for 1 minute if a creature touches the arch with a six-fingered gauntlet (one can be found in {@area area 14b|7be|x}).

Characters must be 14th level or higher to pass through this gate (see "{@area Jhesiyra Kestellharp|016|x}"). The first creature to pass through the gate triggers an elder rune (see "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}").
A creature that passes through the gate appears in {@area area 7a on level 17|8e3|x}, in the closest unoccupied space next to the identical gate located there.

entries: The githzerai have correctly deduced that a six-fingered gauntlet is required to activate the gate but don't know where to find such an item. (The characters can locate one in area 14b. A character proficient with smith's tools can also fashion one out of scrap metal in a tenday using an intact forge.)

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Yrlakka carries a {@item Potion of Fire Resistance||potion of resistance (fire)} in a tiny crystal vial fastened to a cord around his right ankle, and he has a {@item wand of magic detection} hanging from his belt.

entries.name: 24d. Fountain
entries: In the west half of the room, a semicircular fountain emerges from the north wall. Fresh water springs from the mouth of a stone trout held in the arms of a merman bas-relief carved above the fountain's basin, which is filled almost to the brim.
The water pouring into the fountain is drinkable. It drains out slowly through holes along the inside lip of the basin.

entries.name: 25. Abandoned Smithy
entries: Characters who listen at the doors to these rooms can easily hear the clanging of hammers striking metal, even though the forge was destroyed and abandoned long ago. The sounds are illusory effects created by the Mad Mage (see "{@area Halaster's Lair|bb9|x}") that end when any door to the smithy is opened.

entries.name: 25a. Empty Storage Room
entries: Raw metal was stored here until it could be cast into weapons and armor. Now, the room has been mostly cleared out, and the door that leads to {@area area 25b|7e3|x} has been smashed to rubble.

What looks like a large iron book lies facedown on the floor in the northeast corner. Closer inspection reveals that the object is a cast-iron mold for smelting metal ingots. The hinged covers form the top and bottom halves of an ingot mold last used by duergar long ago. One side of the mold bears the image of a dwarf's head in profile, the other an image of a mind flayer's skull.

entries.name: 25b. Destroyed Forge
entries: This room contains a rusty iron anvil and the shattered remains of a stone forge, cold and dark for centuries. Bare iron hooks line the walls, the floor is strewn with rubble, and the door to {@area area 25a|7e2|x} has been smashed.
If you haven't done so in a while, remind the players that their characters can't shake the feeling that they're being observed (one of Netherskull's regional effects).

entries.name: 26. Statue of Moradin
entries: This 20-foot-high, domed chamber is dominated by a 12-foot-tall stone statue of Moradin, the great dwarven god of the forge. It stands in the middle of the room facing the only exit. The statue is veined with bright mithral, and with one hand it raises a stone hammer carved with faintly glowing runes. A steel plaque at the base of the statue reads in Dwarvish, "All that is made can be unmade."

The statue can't be budged or damaged. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals powerful auras of abjuration and transmutation magic surrounding both it and the hammer, which cannot be separated from one another.

entries.name: Teleport Trap
entries: This trap fills the 10-foot square directly in front of the statue. A creature teleported by this trap arrives at a location determined by rolling a {@dice d20} and consulting the following table:

entries.name: Additional Effect: Moradin Smash
entries: When a creature is teleported to this location from another teleport trap, a disembodied voice shouts, "Teleported!" at the same moment the statue of Moradin animates and takes a swing at the creature with its hammer. The target must succeed on a DC 17 Dexterity saving throw or take 40 ({@dice 6d10 + 7}) force damage. Any creature reduced to 0 hit points by this damage is disintegrated, along with all items it is wearing and carrying except for artifacts. After swinging the hammer once, the statue reverts to its inanimate state until the trap is triggered again.

entries.name: 27. Mark of Death
entries: Halaster captured a dwarf vampire named {@creature Zorak Lightdrinker|WDMM} and magically bound him here.

{@b Open Pit}. A 20-foot-long, 40-foot-deep pit spans the width of the corridor. Blood stains the pit's sheer walls, which are too smooth to climb without climbing gear, magic, or a trait such as Spider Climb.

{@b Sarcophagus}. At the bottom of the pit rests a 6-foot-long, 3-foot-wide alabaster sarcophagus draped in cobwebs. Its lid is carved to resemble a giant bat with folded wings. (The sarcophagus contains a vampire.) Floating above the vessel is a magic rune that glows as bright as a candle flame.

A character who understands Dwarvish recognizes the glowing, magical rune as a dwarven symbol of death (identical to the one inscribed on the door to {@area area 14a|7bc|x}). The first time a creature crosses from one side of the pit to the other, the rune disappears and imprints itself as a death mark on a visible portion of the creature's face or body. The mark disappears when its bearer dies or when the vampire is destroyed. Only a {@spell wish} spell or a deity can remove a death mark otherwise.

The sarcophagus at the bottom of the pit is a 2,000-pound chunk of hollowed-out alabaster. {@creature Zorak Lightdrinker|WDMM}, a vampire in mist form, is trapped inside. When the death mark is imprinted on a creature, the sarcophagus crumbles to dust and Zorak is released. The sarcophagus is otherwise indestructible.

A {@spell geas} spell cast by Halaster compels Zorak to hunt down and destroy the creature bearing the death mark, singling out that target above all others. Zorak knows the exact location of the marked creature while the two of them are on the same plane of existence. Slaying the bearer of the death mark frees Zorak from Halaster's {@spell geas} spell, whereupon the vampire seeks to return to his true lair in the Underdark.

If a successful {@spell dispel magic} spell is cast on the rune (DC 19) before it imprints on a creature, the rune disappears for 1 minute, allowing creatures to cross the pit in the meantime without the rune imprinting on any of them.

entries.name: Dwarf Vampire
entries: {@creature Zorak Lightdrinker|WDMM} is a shield dwarf {@creature vampire}, with a challenge rating of 14 (11,500 XP) and these additional changes:

items: Zorak has these racial traits: He speaks Common and Dwarvish. He has resistance to poison damage and advantage on saving throws against poison.
He wears plate armor (AC 18), wields a {@item dwarven thrower}, and gains the action options described below.

entries.name: Multiattack
entries: Zorak makes two attacks with his {@item dwarven thrower}, only one of which can be a ranged attack.

entries.name: Dwarven Thrower
entries: {@i Melee or Ranged Weapon Attack}: +12 to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@i Hit}: 11 ({@dice 1d8 + 7}) bludgeoning damage, or 12 ({@dice 1d10 + 7}) bludgeoning damage when used with two hands to make a melee attack. On a ranged attack that hits, the hammer deals an extra {@dice 1d8} bludgeoning damage ({@dice 2d8} if the target is a giant). {@i Hit or Miss}: If thrown, the weapon flies back to Zorak's hand after the attack.

entries.name: 28. Statue of Tharmekhûl
entries: A 12-foot-tall stone statue with {@spell continual flame} spells cast on its eyes stands facing the exit in the middle of this 20-foot-high, domed chamber. The statue represents Tharmekhûl, the dwarven god of fire and molten rock. It holds an obsidian greataxe above its head. A steel plaque at the base of the statue reads in Dwarvish, "Fire is the cure."

The statue can't be budged or damaged. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals powerful auras of abjuration and transmutation magic surrounding both the statue and the axe, which can't be separated from one another.

entries.name: Teleport Trap
entries: This trap fills the 10-foot square directly in front of the statue. A creature teleported by this trap arrives at a location determined by rolling a {@dice d20} and consulting the following table:

entries.name: Additional Effect: Shearing Flame
entries: When a creature is teleported to this location from another teleport trap, a disembodied voice shouts, "Teleported!" at the same moment the statue of Tharmekhûl animates and takes a swing at the creature. Flames spread across its obsidian axe as it slashes. The axe is considered a magic weapon in the statue's grasp. The target must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or take 16 ({@dice 2d12 + 5}) slashing damage plus 11 ({@dice 2d10}) fire damage. After swinging the axe once, the statue reverts to its inanimate state until the trap is triggered again.

entries.name: 29. Trapped Halls
entries: an unusual pit and an unusual painting await adventurers in these tunnels.

entries.name: 29a. Pit of Brown Mold
entries: This hidden pit (see "{@area Covered Pits|78c|x}") is 50 feet deep, but the floor of the pit is lined with a 10-foot-square patch of brown mold. A creature that falls the distance takes 17 ({@dice 5d6}) bludgeoning damage plus damage from the {@hazard brown mold} (see "{@book Dungeon Hazards|DMG|5|Dungeon Hazards}" in chapter 5 of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}).

entries.name: 29b. Underbrew in Chains
entries: Affixed to the back wall of the western alcove is a stone-framed painting of a scarred male dwarf wearing black plate armor. He is bound by heavy iron chains and shackles anchored to the floor of a dreary dungeon cell. The painting is 3½ feet wide by 7 feet tall.

Thanks to a permanent {@spell Nystul's magic aura} spell cast on the painting, a {@spell detect magic} spell does not reveal that the painting is magical. It is a magical prison that can hold one humanoid creature at a time. The first humanoid creature that approaches within 5 feet of the painting must succeed on a DC 22 Charisma saving throw or be magically pulled into it, switching places with the dwarf currently trapped inside (see below). A humanoid drawn into the painting finds itself chained in an extradimensional cell 10 feet on a side. While trapped in the cell, the creature is {@condition paralyzed}. The painting has AC 11, 4 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. Destroying it frees the trapped creature, which appears in the closest unoccupied space adjacent to the painting.

entries.name: Thwad Underbrew
entries: The dwarf in the painting is a beard-stroking villain named {@creature Thwad Underbrew|WDMM}, a former champion of Gorm Gulthyn (the dwarven god of vigilance) who long ago set out to rid Undermountain of the evil that is {@creature Halaster Blackcloak|WDMM}. Halaster defeated Underbrew but offered to spare the dwarf's life if he vowed to serve the Mad Mage as an enforcer, ridding the dungeon of other invaders. Unwilling to face his own mortal end, Underbrew made this vow and convinced himself over time that the executions he performed were acts of mercy, because those he killed would never be forced to turn against their beliefs as he had. In time, these acts stopped weighing on Underbrew's conscience. In fact, the dwarf began to enjoy his grisly work.
{@creature Thwad Underbrew|WDMM} is a shield dwarf {@creature champion|VGM} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}), with these changes:

items: Underbrew is neutral evil.
Instead of a greatsword, he wields a maul (which deals bludgeoning damage instead of slashing damage).
He has these racial traits: He speaks Common and Dwarvish. He has {@sense darkvision} out to a range of 60 feet, resistance to poison damage, and advantage on saving throws against poison.

entries.name: 30. Halaster's Handiwork
entries: The challenges that await adventurers in these areas can be directly attributed to the Mad Mage.

entries.name: 30a. Netherskull's Biographer

entries: {@b Arch}. A stone arch decorated with gold-inlaid images of soaring dragons is embedded in the middle of the north wall, atop a 3-foot-high red marble dais. Carved into the wall above the arch are the following words in Draconic: "Only a dragon can unlock this gate."

{@b Gong}. A 3-foot-diameter bronze gong hangs from a sturdy wooden frame anchored to the floor near the west wall. The gong is embossed with carvings of ears of corn. A padded wooden mallet dangles from a hook on one of the support posts.

{@b Monsters}. Sitting on the steps of the dais, scribbling madly in a journal with a quill pen, is a wretchedly pale man in a dusty black robe. He is watched over by two {@condition invisible} {@creature Nycaloth||nycaloths}.

To flatter Netherskull, Halaster assigned a would-be apprentice to chronicle the death tyrant's history in a series of journals. This biographer is a skittish, ill-bred, and unkempt male human in his thirties named {@creature Kavil|WDMM} Mereshanter. {@creature Kavil|WDMM} is a {@creature mage}, with these changes:

items: {@creature Kavil|WDMM} is neutral evil.
He speaks Dwarvish, Common, Giant, and Undercommon.

entries: {@creature Kavil|WDMM} was denied admittance to Dweomercore ({@adventure level 9|WDMM|9}), and Halaster robbed him of his spellbook. The Mad Mage has promised to return the book once {@creature Kavil|WDMM} completes his work. (In fact, Halaster has misplaced the spellbook, though {@creature Kavil|WDMM} is unaware of this.)

As Netherskull's appointed biographer, {@creature Kavil|WDMM} is expected to earn the death tyrant's trust, but Netherskull trusts no wizard, and has been reluctant to grant interviews. {@creature Kavil|WDMM} has instead filled one journal after another with his own narrative concoctions and self-pitying asides. The biography is a mostly fictionalized, somewhat sensationalized version of Netherskull's life, death, and undeath. {@creature Kavil|WDMM} knows that anyone who reads this drivel won't be fooled, but he's hoping the deluge of words will impress Halaster while simultaneously discouraging close examination of the work.

{@creature Kavil|WDMM} won't start a fight, but he sides with the nycaloths if a battle erupts, which is likely since the fiends have orders to slay intruders. If reduced to 33 hit points or fewer, {@creature Kavil|WDMM} switches sides and offers information in exchange for his life. He knows one random Undermountain secret, determined by drawing a card from the Secrets Deck (see {@adventure appendix C|WDMM|27}), as well as a secret way into Netherskull's lair (see {@area area 39b|815|x}). {@creature Kavil|WDMM} isn't aware of the secret door that leads to {@area area 30b|7f8|x}.

Characters who spend at least 10 minutes poring over {@creature Kavil|WDMM}'s journal can piece together bits of Netherskull's history and, with a successful DC 10 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check, separate out {@creature Kavil|WDMM}'s gibberish to learn the following truths:

items: The beholder's true name is unknown. It changed its name to Netherskull after becoming a death tyrant.
Netherskull has slain countless interlopers, none more deserving of death than a pompous human paladin named {@creature Fidelio|WDMM}, who wept bitter tears before his disintegration.
Netherskull's primary goals are to destroy Halaster and take over Undermountain.

entries.name: Arch Gate to Level 18
entries: The arch in the north wall is one of Halaster's magic gates (see "{@area Gates|028|x}"). The arch's gold inlay can't be removed. The rules of this gate are as follows:

items: The gate opens for 1 minute when a real or illusory dragon touches the arch. An artistic rendering of a dragon, such as a dragon-shaped figurine or a drawing of a dragon, also opens the gate.

Characters must be at least 15th level or higher to pass through this gate (see "{@area Jhesiyra Kestellharp|016|x}"). The first creature to pass through the gate triggers an elder rune (see "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}").
A creature that passes through the gate appears in {@area area 16 on level 18|92d|x}, in the closest unoccupied space next to the identical gate located there.

entries.name: Gong
entries: A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of conjuration magic around the gong. If the gong is struck with the mallet, three items appear on the floor before it: a small clay bowl filled with bland, edible food (hunks of bread and cheese, strips of meat, and dried nuts); an empty tin cup; and a glass carafe containing 1 gallon of water. The items disappear after 1 hour. Removing any of these items from the room also causes them to vanish. Once it is used to summon food and water, the gong can't do so again until the next dawn. If the gong is taken from this room, it loses its magical property.

entries.name: 30b. Play-by-Play Generator
entries: This dusty room has a 10-foot-high ceiling. A 3-foot cube composed of equal parts adamantine and flesh sits atop a 3-foot-tall hexagonal plinth of carved stone. The surface of the cube facing the secret door bears Halaster's fleshy, grimacing visage.
Disturbing the cube causes it to sprout spindly arms, legs, and wings. It then fights until destroyed. It has the statistics of a {@creature quadrone}, with these changes:

items: The cube is chaotic evil.
It speaks Common and is the source of Halaster's play-by-play (see "{@area Halaster's Play-by-Play|78d|x}").

Whenever it would normally make a shortbow attack, it instead hurls a magic dart at a target it can see up to 60 feet away from it. Each dart hits its target automatically (no attack roll required) for 5 ({@dice 2d4}) force damage.

entries: As the cube attacks, it continues its play-by-play routine, commentating its battle with the adventurers. Destroying the cube ends the play-by-play throughout the Obstacle Course.

entries.name: Hidden Key
entries: A secret compartment is hidden atop the hexagonal plinth. Finding it requires a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. It contains a 6-inch-long key carved from a dragon's finger bone, shaped like an H. This key, which is identical to the one in area 19, unlocks the doors to {@area area 39c|816|x}.
{@b Brazier}. A 5-foot-tall, 7-foot-diameter stone brazier dominates the northwest part of the room. Eight embers gather and swirl above the empty brazier like fireflies.
{@b Statue}. A 3-foot-tall, 5-foot-long statue of a giant toad sits beside a 10-foot-square, 50-foot-deep open pit in the southeastern part of the room.
{@b Alcove}. An empty alcove to the north contains a teleport trap (see "{@area Teleport Traps|78d|x}").

entries.name: Brazier
entries: The eight embers swirling above the brazier radiate auras of conjuration and transmutation magic under the scrutiny of a {@spell detect magic} spell or similar magic.

The embers easily slip through the grasp of {@spell mage hand} spells and other magical effects, but a creature within reach of the brazier can use an action to try to catch an ember, doing so with a successful DC 20 Dexterity check. Catching an ember causes it to vanish and triggers a random magical effect, determined by rolling a {@dice d6} and consulting the Magic Embers table. Any creature that gains a benefit also gains awareness of that benefit. Embers that are caught do not reappear.

entries.caption: Magic Embers
rows: The creature that caught the ember gains immunity to fire damage for the next 24 hours.
The ember becomes a single bead from a {@i necklace of {@spell Fireball|PHB|fireballs}}.
The creature that caught the ember gains the ability to speak and understand Ignan for the next 24 hours (useful for communicating with the mephits and lava children on this level).
The ember becomes an {@item elemental gem} (fire).
The ember becomes a diamond worth 5,000 gp.
The ember becomes a tiny iron key that unlocks the jaws of the giant toad statue.

entries.name: Giant Toad Statue
entries: The giant toad statue merges seamlessly with the floor and can't be moved. A character who inspects the statue and succeeds on a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check notices two things: the statue's jaws are hinged but locked shut, and a tiny keyhole is positioned just above its bulbous eyes. Inserting the proper key into the keyhole causes the statue's hinged mouth to open, as does a {@spell knock} spell or similar magic. The mouth can also be opened by a character using thieves' tools who succeeds on a DC 20 Dexterity check.

Opening the statue's mouth causes a 50-foot rope ladder to tumble out, extending all the way to the bottom of the pit. The ladder is securely attached to a stone bar lodged in the toad's throat, and characters can use it to safely climb in and out of the pit.

entries.name: Open Pit
entries: This 50-foot-deep pit has walls too smooth to climb without climbing gear or a special climbing trait such as Spider Climb. An antimagic field like that created by an {@spell antimagic field} spell fills the uppermost 40 feet of the pit, leaving a 10-foot cube at the bottom unaffected.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Any magic items teleported away by the {@creature statue of Vergadain|WDMM} in {@area area 23|7d3|x} or by the teleport trap in this room lie unharmed at the bottom of the pit.

entries.name: Teleport Trap
entries: This trap fills the alcove. A creature teleported by this trap arrives at a location determined by rolling a {@dice d20} and consulting the following table:

entries.name: Additional Effect: Magic Item Theft
entries: When a creature is teleported to this location from another teleport trap, any magic items in its possession are teleported to the bottom of the pit in this room.

entries.name: 32. Empty Junction
entries: Scrawled in chalk on the west wall is the word "LOOT" in Dwarvish, with an arrow pointing toward the southwest tunnel.

entries.name: 33. Shots in the Dark
entries: This room is empty except for a pair of loaded wooden ballistae aimed squarely at the doors. When either door is opened, magic causes the ballista across from the door to discharge its wooden bolt, targeting the first creature in its path. Each ballista has a +6 bonus to hit and deals 16 ({@dice 3d10}) piercing damage on a hit.
The ballistae are securely bolted to the floor, and each comes equipped with one bolt.

entries.name: 34. Chasm's Edge
entries: This hall terminates abruptly at the edge of the lava-lit chasm. If the characters make a lot of noise here, they attract the attention of Netherskull in {@area area 39c|816|x}, who flies into the chasm and attacks them.
{@b Chasm}. The southern end of this chamber has collapsed into a lava-filled chasm (see {@area area 40|818|x}). Sweltering heat from the lava fills the room.
{@b Doors}. The northern half of the room is empty except for two doors. The door in the north wall is round and made of adamantine (see {@area area 39c|816|x}).

{@b Corpse}. Between the northern and southern halves of the room, where the room is narrowest, a female dwarf has fallen prey to a scythe trap, her dead body pinned between the trap's blades and the western wall. Halaster has placed a teleport trap (see "{@area Teleport Traps|78d|x}") just south of the scythe trap.

entries.name: Scythe Trap
entries: If the dead dwarf is disturbed, the scythe blades shatter due to the built-up pressure from the gears hidden in the walls. Any creature within 5 feet of the broken trap must succeed on a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw or be struck by flying broken blades for 9 ({@dice 2d8}) slashing damage. A character proficient with thieves' tools can use them to try to safely release the pressure and render the trap harmless, doing so with a successful DC 20 Dexterity check. If this check fails by 5 or more, the trap flies apart as described above.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The dead dwarf was an adventuring rogue named Xelba Shunlight. She clutches a shortsword and wears torn and bloody studded leather armor, as well as a dungeoneer's pack (with no rations), a mess kit, a miner's pick, and a random trinket (roll on the {@item Trinket|phb|Trinkets} table in chapter 5 of the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}). Tied to her waist is a hide pouch that contains a {@item figurine of wondrous power} (onyx dog).

entries.name: Teleport Trap
entries: A creature teleported by this trap arrives at a location determined by rolling a {@dice d20} and consulting the following table:

entries.name: 36. Looted Vaults
entries: These dwarven vaults were looted long ago. The heavy iron vault doors have all been warped and pulled away from their frames, and they can no longer be closed.

entries.name: 36a. Teleport Trap
entries: A creature teleported by this trap arrives at a location determined by rolling a {@dice d20} and consulting the following table:

entries.name: 36b. Gold-Veined Vault
entries: The lead door that once secured this room has been torn open with such force that it's bent and hanging from a single hinge.

This vault was plundered long ago. The 10-foot-high walls are lined with stone bricks veined with gold. A few of the bricks have come loose, revealing thin sheets of lead behind them. These lead sheets are designed to prevent magical senses from piercing the vault.

entries.name: 36c. Obsidian Vault
entries: The lead door that once secured this room is bent inward at the bottom, creating a 3-foot-high triangular hole through which Medium and smaller creatures can fit.

Like {@area area 36b|80c|x}, this vault was plundered long ago. The 10-foot-high walls are lined with obsidian bricks, behind which are thin sheets of lead designed to keep magical senses from peering inside.

entries.name: 36d. Damaged Stone Vault

entries: {@b Door}. The lead door that once secured this room has been torn off its hinges and lies on the floor.
{@b Chasm}. The southwest corner of the chamber has fallen away, revealing a lava-filled chasm (see {@area area 40|818|x}).

The lava children in {@area area 40b|81a|x} like to climb up to this room and leap off the edge into the lava below. If the characters didn't deal with the lava children already, they might encounter one or more of them here.

entries.name: 37. Harmless Halaster Statue
entries: This cavern has a jagged, 20-foot-high ceiling. The floor is smooth and level except for a sloping tunnel that descends to {@adventure level 16|WDMM|16}.

In the middle of the cave stands a life-size statue of Halaster with lidless eyes carved into its flowing robe. The statue is a Medium object with AC 17, 45 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. A character can topple the statue with a successful DC 15 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: 38. Zombie Horde

entries: {@b Zombies}. The stench of death fills this 20-foot-high cavern, which contains forty {@creature Zombie||zombies} in various states of decay. They shamble about aimlessly.
{@b Sinkhole}. A 70-foot-deep sinkhole has formed near the east wall.

The zombies are the remains of humanoids killed by Netherskull and animated by its Negative Energy Cone. They include several humans and dwarves, as well as a few elves, drow, tieflings, quaggoths, duergar, hobgoblins, troglodytes, and githyanki. Until Netherskull summons them, the zombies remain here and attack intruders on sight. You can expedite combat by dividing the zombies into mobs of ten or fewer and using the mob rules in {@book chapter 8|DMG|8|Handling Mobs} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}.

entries.name: 39. Netherskull's Sanctum
entries: Adventurers who explore this area are doomed to face Netherskull the death tyrant if they haven't done so already. Netherskull can't be surprised in its lair.

entries.name: 39a. Hanging Beholder Statue
entries: Hanging from the 30-foot-high, domed ceiling by three iron chains is a 6-foot-diameter carved stone beholder. Netherskull carved the statue using its carefully manipulated Disintegration Ray, but the rough sculpture is clearly the work of a talentless amateur. Each chain has AC 19, 25 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. Breaking all three chains causes the statue to fall and shatter on the floor.

entries.name: 39b. Secret Tunnel
entries: This dusty passage circumvents the adamantine doors to Netherskull's lair (see {@area area 39c|816|x}) and is hidden behind two secret doors. The death tyrant uses its Telekinetic Ray to open and close the secret doors when it comes and goes through this tunnel.

entries.name: 39c. Death Tyrant
entries: All doors leading to this area are 1-foot-thick, 7-foot-diameter adamantine disks molded to look like concentric rings of bones with a leering human skull at the center. The skull's nose cavity contains an adamantine keyhole. When one of Halaster's bone keys (see {@area areas 19|7ca|x} and {@area 30b|7f8}) is inserted into the lock and turned 90 degrees clockwise, four bolt locks slide back from the surrounding walls, and the door swings inward on adamantine hinges. The door remains open until it is closed, and the key can be removed at any time. Without the proper key, it takes four separate {@spell knock} spells to open one of these doors, each spell causing one bolt to slide back. The doors are otherwise impregnable.

There is no keyhole on the inside of the doors. Instead, each door has an adamantine wheel in the middle of it that must be turned counterclockwise to slide back the bolts. This wheel can also be used as a handle to pull the heavy door open. When Netherskull wants to leave the room through a door, it uses its Telekinetic Ray to turn the wheel and leaves the door open until it returns.

entries.name: Netherskull
entries: Unless it has been defeated elsewhere, the {@creature death tyrant} floats 30 feet above the stone-tiled floor of this 40-foot-high chamber. Netherskull seeks to destroy intruders and animate their corpses, turning them into zombie thralls. It calls forth the zombies in {@area area 38|811|x} (assuming they haven't been defeated) and commands them to attack all intruders.

If the characters haven't silenced the level's play-by-play announcer (see "{@area Halaster's Play-by-Play|78d|x}"), it becomes increasingly excited as the battle with the death tyrant unfolds. If they defeat Netherskull, the announcer screams, "How could this happen?! This is unbelievable! This might be the greatest upset in the history of Undermountain!" It then falls silent for the rest of the time the characters spend on this level.

entries.name: 40. Netherskull's Chasm
entries: The death tyrant carved out this immense chasm using its Disintegration Ray, and Halaster added his own touches by flooding it with lava and confounding magical flight within the chasm.

Spells and magic items that allow creatures to fly are suppressed within the chasm. Any character who enters the chasm under the effect of a {@spell fly} spell or similar magic goes hurtling down into the lava. Spells that slow one's fall (such as {@spell feather fall}) function normally.

Creatures who spend 1 hour or longer in the chasm or in any of the areas open to it are susceptible to the effects of extreme heat (as described in {@book chapter 5|DMG|5|Weather} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}). The chasm is brightly lit by the lava, which fills the bottom of the chasm to a depth of 20 feet. A creature that enters the lava for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there takes 55 ({@dice 10d10}) fire damage.

The surface of the lava is 30 feet below the floor level of the Obstacle Course. The walls in between are sloped and have abundant handholds and footholds. Climbing them requires a successful DC 10 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check; on a check that fails by 5 or more, the creature slips and falls into the lava.

entries.name: 40a. Magma Mephits
entries: Four {@creature Magma Mephit||magma mephits} lounge in this small lava pool. If the characters parley with the mephits in a language they understand, the mephits try to lure the characters toward {@area area 39c|816|x}, hoping they'll either kill Netherskull or die in the attempt. The mephits detest the death tyrant and care only about their own well-being.

entries.name: 40b. Lava Children's Pool
entries: Eight {@creature Lava Child|WDMM|lava children} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) swim and play in this lava pool. They also climb up to area 36d and do cannonballs into the lava from the top of the 30-foot-high ledge.

entries.name: 40c. Teleport Trap Destination
entries: A creature teleported to this location by another teleport trap appears 30 feet above the lava and immediately plunges into it unless the creature has some way to stop the fall. (Remember that spells and magic items that allow creatures to fly are suppressed within the chasm.)
Unlike other teleport traps in the Obstacle Course, this trap doesn't teleport creatures to other locations.

entries.name: 40d. Magma Mephits' Pool
entries: Six {@creature Lava Child|WDMM|lava children} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) and seven {@creature Magma Mephit||magma mephits} frolic in this lava pool and watch for intruders in {@area areas 18|7c8|x} and {@area 21|7ce}. If intruders are detected, the mephits incite the lava children into climbing up the walls to attack the new arrivals, while the mephits use their breath weapons and keep their distance.

entries.name: Aftermath
entries: Netherskull's regional effects end with the death tyrant's destruction, and Halaster takes his time replacing the creature. Eventually he settles on abducting several beholders, releasing them in the Obstacle Course, and letting them vie for control of the level until only one remains. Halaster plans to help the winner transform itself into a new death tyrant.

Although most of the Obstacle Course's remaining inhabitants have no intention of leaving anytime soon, the githzerai stay only as long as they must to reunite with their missing comrade and ensure the destruction of the mind flayer colony on {@adventure level 17|WDMM|17}.

data.name: Level 16: Crystal Labyrinth
entries: Githyanki recently turned the Crystal Labyrinth into an outpost of their interplanar empire. It houses a gate to Stardock, a hollowed-out asteroid in orbit around the planet Toril (one of many that form the asteroid cluster known as the Tears of Selûne). Together, the Crystal Labyrinth and Stardock are designed for four 14th-level characters. Those who defeat the monsters on this level should gain enough XP to advance halfway to 15th level.

Before running this level of Undermountain, you should review the "Gith" entry in the {@book Monster Manual|MM}, because it contains information that will help you roleplay githyanki effectively. Additional information about githyanki society can be found in {@book Mordenkainen's Tome of Foes|MTF}, although that resource is not required to run the Crystal Labyrinth.

entries.name: What Dwells Here?
entries: Githyanki tracking a splinter colony of mind flayers to Undermountain seized this level and turned what was once a crystalline maze into a fortress. From here, they launch attacks against the mind flayers on {@adventure level 17|WDMM|17}. The githyanki also transformed Stardock into a crèche: a fortress dedicated to raising and training young warriors. Because creatures do not age on the Astral Plane, the githyanki must bring their offspring to the Material Plane to mature. Unfamiliar with the asteroid's actual name, the githyanki refer to Stardock as Crèche K'liir.

entries.name: The Original Crystal Labyrinth
entries: {@i Undermountain: Stardock}, written by Steven E. Schend and published in 1997, was the third of three modules in the short-lived "Dungeon Crawl" series of adventures designed for the second edition D&D game. {@i Waterdeep: Dungeon of the Mad Mage} presents alternative versions of the Crystal Labyrinth and Stardock scaled for fifth edition and this product. If you want to expand this level of Undermountain, the original adventure would be a fine source of inspiration.

entries.name: Githyanki
entries: The militaristic githyanki who live in the Crystal Labyrinth and Stardock have three important tasks: protect the crèche, train young githyanki warriors, and destroy the mind flayer colony in Seadeeps ({@adventure level 17|WDMM|17}).

entries.name: Knights and the Draconic Tongue
entries: Githyanki knights encountered in the Crystal Labyrinth and Stardock speak Draconic in addition to their native language of Gith—all the better to communicate with their red dragon mounts.

entries.name: Githyanki Leaders
entries: The githyanki are led by {@creature Al'chaia|WDMM}, a knight who is cruel to her trainees and soldiers. {@creature Al'chaia|WDMM} recently acquired a {@item manual of gainful exercise} and a {@item tome of clear thought}, and she has promised to award both items to her most accomplished soldier. In truth, she plans to read these tomes to gain their benefits herself, but uses the promise of this reward to trick her troops into running themselves ragged. {@creature Al'chaia|WDMM}'s second in command, Urlon, is tired of the abuse and plots against her.

entries.name: Red Dragons
entries: {@creature Ashtyrranthor|WDMM}, an adult red dragon, is mother to six young red dragons that live in the Crystal Labyrinth and defend Crèche K'liir. {@creature Ashtyrranthor|WDMM}'s children are named Ashranthax, Blazutranc, Infernexus, Meteoranzym, Smoakcant, and Zolcharrx.

entries.name: Astyrranthor
entries: {@creature Ashtyrranthor|WDMM} can't treat Stardock as her lair, so she has no lair actions here. However, she has the following Innate Spellcasting trait:

entries.name: Innate Spellcasting
entries: {@creature Ashtyrranthor|WDMM}'s innate spellcasting ability is Charisma. She can innately cast the following spells, requiring no material components:
1/day each: {@spell alarm}, {@spell detect magic}, {@spell gaseous form}, {@spell misty step}, {@spell passwall}, {@spell see invisibility}

{@creature Ashtyrranthor|WDMM} spends most of her time on the outer surface of the asteroid, prowling through the wreckage of spacefaring vessels that crashed into Stardock long ago. If combat breaks out inside Crèche K'liir, there is a {@chance 10|10 percent} chance that she hears the disturbance. She investigates immediately, joining the battle in progress and using her {@spell gaseous form}, {@spell misty step}, and {@spell passwall} spells to enter hard-to-reach locations. {@creature Ashtyrranthor|WDMM} also keeps a specific watch over {@area areas 12f|857|x}, {@area 13|85a}, and {@area 16a|864} from outside the asteroid. If she sees trouble or intruders in those areas, she attacks at once.

entries.name: Crystal Golems
entries: Crystal golems found throughout the Crystal Labyrinth look like 10-foot-tall githyanki warriors. They understand Gith but can't speak, and they attack any creatures that don't look like githyanki or red dragons. Each {@creature crystal golem|wdmm} is a stone golem with these additional traits:

entries.name: Illumination
entries: The golem magically sheds bright light in a 30-foot radius and dim light for an additional 30 feet. This light goes out when the golem is destroyed.

entries.name: Light Intensity
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 10 feet of the illuminated golem and can see the golem must succeed on a DC 17 Wisdom saving throw or be {@condition blinded} until the start of the creature's next turn.

A creature can avert its eyes to avoid the saving throw at the start of its turn. If the creature does so, it can't see the golem until the start of its next turn, when it can avert its eyes again. If the creature looks at the golem in the meantime, it must immediately make the save.

entries.name: Crystal Dungeon
entries: All area descriptions for this location are keyed to map 16. As one descends from {@adventure level 15|WDMM|15} or climbs up from {@adventure level 17|WDMM|17}, the rough stone walls, floor, and ceiling give way to ever-widening veins of luminous crystal until every surface is made of the substance. In many areas, the githyanki have torn down the crystalline walls to create larger spaces.
Unless otherwise noted, the crystal dungeon has the following unique features:

items: The dungeon is brightly lit throughout. The crystal walls, ceilings, and floor emit magical light that changes color every 10 minutes, shifting through all the hues of the rainbow.
Doors are carved from single slabs of opaque white crystal similar in weight and consistency to stone.

entries.name: 1. Entry Hall
entries: A {@creature crystal golem|WDMM} (see the "{@area Crystal Golems|825|x}" sidebar) stands guard here. It attacks any creature not escorted by a githyanki or a red dragon. If combat erupts here, the githyanki warriors from area 2a investigate.

entries.name: 2. Western Cavern
entries: The githyanki knocked down several walls to create this chamber, and much of the debris has yet to be cleared.

entries.name: 2a. Ilmei's Watch

entries: {@b Crystal Stalactite}. A 10-foot-long crystal stalactite hangs above a pit filled with silvery mist. Encased in the stalactite is Ilmei, a female {@creature githyanki gish|MTF} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25} for statistics; see also "{@area Crystal Stalactites|832|x}").
{@b Guards}. Around the pit, four {@creature Githyanki Warrior||githyanki warriors} (two males and two females) spar with each other to pass the time.
Fresh out of Crèche K'liir, the young githyanki warriors are hostile toward intruders. If two of them fall, the remaining ones retreat to {@area area 3b|835|x} or dive into the pit.
Creatures that fall into the pit are immediately transported to the Astral Plane (see {@book chapter 2|DMG|2|Astral Plane} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG} for more information).

entries.name: 2b. Dragon Engravings
entries: The walls of this chamber are engraved with images of armored githyanki knights riding red dragons.

entries.name: 2c. Illithid Heads
entries: Twelve severed mind flayer heads are mounted on the east and west walls of this partially destroyed area. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of necromancy magic around each head, which is a Tiny object with AC 5, 3 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. Reducing a head to 0 hit points destroys it. Whenever a head is destroyed, any remaining mind flayer heads in the area that haven't been destroyed emit a telepathic scream. Each creature in the room takes {@dice 1d6} psychic damage for each screaming head (maximum {@dice 12d6}).

entries.name: 3. Main Cavern
entries: Githyanki twins named Arbez and Surlock are contained within crystal stalactites in this cavern.

entries.name: 3a. Arbez's Watch
entries: The creatures in area 3b investigate any disturbance in this portion of the cavern, which contains the following:

{@b Crystal Stalactite}. A 10-foot-long crystal stalactite hangs above a pit filled with silvery mist. Encased in the stalactite is Arbez, a male {@creature githyanki gish|MTF} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25} for statistics; see also "Crystal Stalactites").
{@b Straw Dummies}. Five freestanding straw dummies with the rough forms of mind flayers (marked X on map 16) stand north of the pit.
Creatures that fall into the pit are immediately transported to the Astral Plane (see {@book chapter 2|DMG|2|Astral Plane} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG} for more information).

Githyanki warriors use the straw dummies as targets in combat training exercises. Each is a Medium object with AC 10, 10 hit points, immunity to poison and psychic damage, and vulnerability to fire damage.

entries.name: Crystal Stalactites
entries: Four githyanki gish (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) are encased in transparent crystal stalactites in {@area areas 2|82c|x}, {@area 3|831}, and {@area 6|83b}. While encased, these githyanki remain aware of their surroundings but don't require air, food, or water. Until the crystal around them is destroyed, they can't be targeted by attacks or subjected to magical effects. Moreover, they are {@condition restrained} and can't use their War Magic feature or make longsword attacks. They cast spells through the crystal as though it wasn't there.

Each crystal stalactite is a Large inanimate object with AC 15, 80 hit points, and immunity to poison and psychic damage. A stalactite reduced to 0 hit points shatters, freeing the githyanki within. A githyanki whose stalactite is destroyed is no longer {@condition restrained} by it and falls into the pit of silvery mist below it, whereupon it returns to the Astral Plane.

entries.name: 3b. Surlock's Watch

entries: {@b Crystal Stalactite}. A 10-foot-long crystal stalactite hangs above a pit filled with silvery mist. Encased in the stalactite is Surlock, a male {@creature githyanki gish|MTF} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25} for statistics; see also the "Crystal Stalactites" sidebar).
{@b Knight and Dragon}. Near the eastern edge of the pit, a female {@creature githyanki knight} named Deslarr sits astride Ashranthax, a female {@creature young red dragon}.

If they are not alerted to the characters' presence, Deslarr and the dragon chat in Draconic about how many illithids they must kill to prove themselves worthy of "{@creature Al'chaia|WDMM}'s magic books." They fight to the death.
Creatures that fall into the pit are immediately transported to the Astral Plane (see {@book chapter 2|DMG|2|Astral Plane} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG} for more information).

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Deslarr carries a {@i Stardock rod} (see "{@area Stardock Rods|847|x}"). Her plate armor is set with eight black jaspers (50 gp each) and eight amber gemstones (100 gp each).

entries.name: 4. Barracks
entries: Ten beds with pale white crystal frames are set along the walls. At any given time, ten {@creature Githyanki Warrior||githyanki warriors} are resting in this area. If they have not been alerted, the githyanki are asleep when the characters arrive. They are hostile toward intruders and fight to the death.

entries.name: 5. Prison Cell
entries: The crystal doors to this room are magically locked, but they open automatically for any creature that carries a {@i Stardock rod} (see "{@area Stardock Rods|847|x}"). There are no physical locks to be picked, but a {@spell knock} spell or similar magic also opens a door.
Magic wards in the room prevent any creature from teleporting into or out of it.

entries.name: Marquox
entries: A {@creature mind flayer} named Marquox uses its {@spell levitate} spell to float in the center of this otherwise empty room. It was captured while it searched this level for its companions, Tel'zact and Yeluit (see {@area area 29c|893|x}).

Marquox doesn't know why the githyanki are keeping it alive, but it knows it won't survive long in their captivity. If the characters don't attack it at once, Marquox proposes a deal. If they free it and help it rescue its companions, Marquox guarantees the party safe passage through level 17. A successful DC 16 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check reveals that the illithid has no intention of making good on its promise. If the githzerai zerths from {@adventure level 15|WDMM|15} are with the party, they refuse to help the mind flayer and insist that the characters kill it. If the characters choose Marquox over them, the githzerai abandon the party and withdraw to {@adventure level 15|WDMM|15}.

Marquox knows about Stardock but has never visited the asteroid. It also knows that the gate to Stardock is in {@area area 11|847|x}, and that a black crystal rod is needed to activate it. If the characters allow it, Marquox follows them to Stardock, fighting alongside them until it reunites with its kin. At that point, the mind flayers either turn against the party (if the characters appear weak) or lure the characters to the mind flayer colony on {@adventure level 17|WDMM|17}, where Extremiton (the colony's ulitharid leader) can decide what to do with them.

entries.name: 6. Eastern Cavern
entries: The githyanki knocked down several walls to create this chamber, and much of the debris remains.

entries.name: 6a. Mirrk's Watch

entries: {@b Crystal Stalactite}. A 10-foot-long crystal stalactite hangs above a pit filled with silvery mist. Encased in the stalactite is Mirrk, a female {@creature githyanki gish|MTF} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25} for statistics; see also "{@area Crystal Stalactites|832|x}").

{@b Guards}. Unless they have been lured elsewhere, six {@creature Githyanki Warrior||githyanki warriors} (three females and three males) stand guard around the edge of the pit in the squares marked W on map 16.

The warriors speak in Gith about their dislike of {@creature Al'chaia|WDMM} and their respect for Urlon. They are hostile toward intruders and fight until three or more of them fall, whereupon the remaining warriors retreat to area 7 or dive into the pit.
Creatures that fall into the pit are immediately transported to the Astral Plane (see {@book chapter 2|DMG|2|Astral Plane} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG} for more information).

entries.name: 6b. Scrying Chamber
entries: The north wall of this chamber hums and glows purple. A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals an aura of divination magic radiating from the wall. Any creature that spends 1 minute touching the wall can cast the {@spell scrying} spell targeting the ulitharid on {@adventure level 17|WDMM|17}, using the wall as a focus. A character who examines the wall can, with a successful DC 14 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check, ascertain that it's a scrying device and figure out how it works.

entries.name: 7. Anti-Illithid Defense
entries: Two crystal golems (see "{@area Crystal Golems|825|x}") guard this room. They attack any creature that enters this area unescorted by a githyanki, a {@creature crystal golem|WDMM}, or a red dragon. If combat breaks out in this chamber, the githyanki warriors in area 6a come to investigate.

A permanent enchantment in this chamber grants any creature in the area advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, and causes the {@spell levitate} and {@spell detect thoughts} spells to automatically fail when cast.

entries.name: 8. Officer Quarters
entries: Four beds with pale white crystal frames are set along the walls. A male {@creature githyanki knight} named Eshant and a male {@creature githyanki gish|MTF} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) named Theru stand in the middle of the room, engaged in a tense debate. Characters who get close to this area without alerting the githyanki hear the two arguing in Gith about which of them is worthier of "{@creature Al'chaia|WDMM}'s magic books." The debate is intense but stops short of physical violence. If the characters don't interrupt, the gish eventually backs down and withdraws to area 9 to cool his heels. Eshant and Theru attack intruders on sight.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Eshant and Theru carry one {@i Stardock rod} apiece (see "{@area Stardock Rods|847|x}").

Eshant's plate armor is set with six black jaspers (50 gp each) and six red spinels (100 gp each). Eshant also carries a {@item potion of greater healing} in a crystal vial worn on a thin platinum chain (25 gp) around his neck.
{@b Stuffed Ulitharid}. A 10-foot-tall, stuffed ulitharid (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) stands in a 15-foot-high alcove along the south wall of the room.
{@b Illithid Heads}. Fifteen mounted mind flayer heads decorate the walls.

entries.name: 10. Golem Laboratory

entries: {@b Urlon}. Urlon, a male {@creature githyanki gish|MTF} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}), is using a set of mason's tools to carve the head of a half-completed {@creature crystal golem|WDMM} lying atop a 10-foot-long, 5-foot-wide, 4-foot-high table in the west side of the room.

{@b Golem}. A {@creature crystal golem|WDMM} (see "{@area Crystal Golems|825|x}") stands guard in the east side of the room, surrounded by shelves stacked with books, spell components, pieces of crystal, and mind flayer skulls.
The {@creature crystal golem|WDMM} doesn't attack unless Urlon orders it to do so, or if the characters attack it or Urlon first.

Urlon does not attack the characters unless he has no other choice. Believing that his superior, {@creature Al'chaia|WDMM}, is a tyrant unfit for command, he tries to use the characters to eliminate her. This is true even if the characters are accompanied by githzerai from {@adventure level 15|WDMM|15}; unlike most githyanki, Urlon sympathizes with githzerai and doesn't regard them with utter contempt.

If the characters are willing to listen, Urlon tells them in Common that {@creature Al'chaia|WDMM} keeps two magic tomes meant to enhance strength and intellect in a chest in her quarters on Crèche K'liir. If the characters offer to kill {@creature Al'chaia|WDMM}, Urlon opens the gate in {@area area 11|847|x} for them. Urlon won't accompany the characters, however, since doing so would surely compromise his ability to assume command once {@creature Al'chaia|WDMM} is dead. He doesn't care whether they keep {@creature Al'chaia|WDMM}'s magic books or not.

To earn the characters' trust, Urlon answers any questions they have about the current state of the Crystal Labyrinth and the asteroid. If the characters attack him, Urlon retreats to Stardock by way of the gate in {@area area 11|847|x} while the {@creature crystal golem|WDMM} covers his escape.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Urlon carries a {@i Stardock rod} (see "{@area Stardock Rods|847|x}"), a set of mason's tools, and a green crystal wand (his arcane focus).
Amid the worthless skulls, spell components, and crystal fragments on the shelves are several books of interest:

items: Wedged between red crystal bookends carved in the likeness of red dragons (250 gp for the pair) is a six-volume doctrine of planar philosophy written in Common titled {@i The Spectrum of Multiversal Beliefs}, which delves deeply into the conflicting cosmic philosophies of several different planar factions. Each volume is worth 250 gp separately, but the complete set is worth 2,500 gp.

Stacked one atop another are three identical spellbooks shared by the githyanki gish. Each of these books contains the spells that Urlon and his fellow gish normally prepare (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}), plus {@spell detect magic}, {@spell fabricate}, {@spell haste}, {@spell hold person}, and {@spell shield}.

entries.name: 11. Stardock Gate
entries: The crystal doors to this room are magically locked, but they open automatically for any creature that carries a {@i Stardock rod} (see "Stardock Rods"). There are no physical locks to be picked, but a {@spell knock} spell or similar magic also opens a door.
В комнате находится следующее:

{@b Golem}. A {@creature crystal golem|WDMM} (see "{@area Crystal Golems|825|x}") stands in the southernmost section of the room. It attacks any creature not escorted by a githyanki, a {@creature crystal golem|WDMM}, or a red dragon.
{@b Gate to Stardock}. In the western section of the room, a stone arch set with glowing red crystals is embedded in the south wall.
{@b Pedestal}. Rising from the floor 10 feet in front of the arch is a 3-foot-high pedestal made of red crystal with a small hole in the top.

Together, the arch and pedestal comprise a teleportation gate. The hole bored into the top of the pedestal is 1 inch wide and 6 inches deep. When a {@i Stardock rod} (see "Stardock Rods") is inserted into the hole, the solid wall inside the arch disappears for 1 minute, replaced by an open doorway to {@area area 12a|84c|x}. This magic gate remains open while the rod is in place and closes 1 minute after the rod is removed from the pedestal. While the gate is open, creatures in this room can clearly see into {@area area 12a|84c|x}, and vice versa.

The pedestal and the archway are impervious to damage, and the red crystals embedded in the arch can't be removed. The first time a creature tries to pry a crystal from the arch, a random elder rune appears above the pedestal, targets a random creature within 60 feet of it, then disappears (see "{@area Elder Runes|027|x}"). Determine the elder rune randomly by drawing a card from the Elder Runes Deck (see {@adventure appendix B|WDMM|26}).

entries.name: Stardock Rods
entries: A {@i Stardock rod} is a 1-foot-long black crystal rod that is needed to open the magic gate in {@area area 11|847|x} and its corresponding gate in area 12a. A {@i Stardock rod} weighs 1 pound, radiates an aura of conjuration magic under the scrutiny of a detect magic spell, and has no other magical properties.

entries.name: Stardock
entries: All area descriptions for this location are keyed to map 16.

Originally carved by dragons, the asteroid known as Stardock orbits the planet Toril—one of hundreds that form the asteroid belt known as the Tears of Selûne. Over ages, illithids, undead mages, and spacefaring pirates have fought over and expanded Stardock's halls, but the asteroid was long abandoned by the time the githyanki and their red dragon allies moved in. The asteroid's features are as follows:

items: The restrictions on magic in Undermountain don't apply here, since Stardock is outside the dungeon.
Interior areas are brightly lit by {@spell continual flame} spells cast on crumbling stone wall sconces.

Tunnels have 20-foot-high arched ceilings, and rooms have flat 25-foot-high ceilings, unless otherwise noted. Staircases are carved out of solid rock and are 30 feet high and 30 feet long. Walls and ceilings are roughly hewn, and floors are smooth.

The asteroid magically generates breathable air that fills Stardock's interior and extends out 120 feet from the asteroid. Beyond this range is the airless void of space. A creature can survive in space for a number of rounds equal to its Constitution modifier (minimum 1 round) before it dies.
The temperature inside the asteroid's air envelope is 70 degrees Fahrenheit unless otherwise noted.

An {@condition invisible} gravity plane cuts through the asteroid along its equator, as illustrated in the Side View of the asteroid on map 16. Creatures and objects inside the asteroid's air envelope fall toward this gravity plane. Creatures and objects inside the asteroid fall toward the floor, as normal.
There are no cardinal directions (north, south, east, or west) in Stardock or in space, and compasses don't function here.

entries: Creatures can propel themselves through space using magic such as {@spell fly} spells, but wings and other non-magical means of propulsion are useless in the frictionless void.

entries.name: 12. Dragons' Domain
entries: {@creature Ashtyrranthor|WDMM} and her six children make their home here. Magic keeps the temperature at 120 degrees Fahrenheit throughout these chambers, making it perfect for the dragons' comfort. Characters who stay in this area for more than 1 hour suffer the effects of {@hazard extreme heat} (see {@book chapter 5|DMG|5|Weather} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}).

entries.name: 12a. Arch Gate

entries: {@b Ceiling}. This room has a 30-foot-high, domed ceiling.
{@b Scales}. The floor is littered with red dragon scales.
{@b Gate to the Crystal Labyrinth}. A stone arch set with glowing red crystals is embedded in the back wall of an alcove.
{@b Pedestal}. Rising from the floor 10 feet in front of the arch is a 3-foot-high pedestal made of red crystal with a small hole in the top.

Inserting a {@i Stardock rod} (see the "{@area Stardock Rods|847|x}," sidebar) into the hole in the pedestal creates an open doorway inside the arch that leads to {@area area 11|847|x}. The pedestal and archway are otherwise identical to those in {@area area 11|847|x}.

Any character who examines the scales and succeeds on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) check realizes that the scales came from multiple owners. Most were shed by an adult red dragon, while a few were cast off by one or more young red dragons.

entries.name: 12b. Tiamat Shrine

entries: {@b Tapestries}. Two beautiful tapestries hang on the walls.
{@b Carving}. Carved into the floor is a stylized, 15-foot-diameter disk-shaped engraving of Tiamat, her five chromatic dragon heads spewing their breath weapons.

One tapestry depicts Tiamat combating twelve storm giants. The other shows Tiamat battling a bearded and bloodied old man in wizard robes with seven golden canaries circling his head. A character who succeeds on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check recognizes the old man as a representation of Bahamut, the god of good dragons, in human form, and the seven canaries as his polymorphed gold dragon advisors.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Each tapestry is 20 feet on a side, weighs 25 pounds, and is worth 750 gp intact.

entries.name: 12c. False Hatchery

entries: {@b Lava Curtain}. A 30-foot-wide curtain of lava along one wall drains into a pool 1 foot deep, 30 feet long, and 10 feet wide. A secret door stands behind the lava curtain, opening into area 12d. The characters can't open or pass through the secret door without coming into contact with the lava.
{@b Eggs}. Six red-speckled dragon eggs sit in the lava pool.
The lava curtain is created magically but is not itself magical. A creature that enters the lava for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there takes 55 ({@dice 10d10}) fire damage.

Each egg is 4 feet tall, hollow, and 500 pounds. A character who inspects the eggs closely and succeeds on a DC 12 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check realizes that they are fakes made of polished stone.

entries.name: 12d. Dragon Hatchery

entries: {@b Lava Pool}. The entire floor is a 1-foot-deep pool of lava. The lava is created magically but is not itself magical. A creature that enters the lava floor for the first time on a turn or starts its turn there takes 55 ({@dice 10d10}) fire damage.
{@b Egg}. A red-speckled dragon egg rests in the lava near the chamber's curved wall.

The red dragon egg stands 4 feet high and weighs 250 pounds. To properly develop, the egg must spend another six months in an environment of extreme heat. When the egg hatches, a {@creature red dragon wyrmling} emerges. The wyrmling is loyal to no one except itself. If the characters steal the egg, {@creature Ashtyrranthor|WDMM} and every other dragon of her line will hunt the characters until the egg is recovered.

entries.name: 12e. False Hoard
entries: Loud noises in this area alert the denizens of {@area areas 12f|857|x} and {@area 13|85a}, who remain where they are but can't be surprised.

{@b Illusion}. A 20-foot-wide, 4-foot-high pile of coins, jewels, and art objects lies on the floor in the 20-foot-square area marked on map 16. The treasure pile is an illusion that can be dispelled (DC 16). A {@spell detect magic} spell reveals its illusory nature. The treasure has no substance, so any physical interaction with the pile also reveals that it's an illusion.
{@b Scales}. The floor around the treasure pile is littered with cast-off red dragon scales.
{@b Statues}. Two 20-foot-tall, gilded statues of dragons of an unknown type stand along one wall.

Characters who examine the scales can tell that they came from a red dragon. A character who succeeds on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Nature}) check realizes that the scales came from multiple dragons. Most were shed by an adult red dragon, while a few were cast off by one or more young red dragons.
The ancient statues testify to the unknown draconic creators of this chamber. They are impervious to damage, which prevents any of their gold leaf from being removed.

entries.name: 12f. Dragons' Hoard
entries: The characters hear the strumming of a lute (see {@area area 13|85a|x}) as they approach this rough-hewn cave, the contents of which are as follows:
{@b Hoard}. An enormous pile of coins and gems fills this chamber. Sleeping under this hoard are two male {@creature Young Red Dragon||young red dragons} named Blazutranc and Meteoranzym.
{@b Tunnel}. A wide tunnel strewn with cast-off red dragon scales breaks through the outer shell of the asteroid and forms a ledge overlooking the planet Toril.

Blazutranc and Meteoranzym are slumbering beneath the treasure pile. Characters who approach quietly and succeed on a DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check spot the gleaming red scales of the dragons beneath the treasure. When they become aware of intruders, the dragons fight until one of them is reduced to 60 hit points, whereupon they both leave the asteroid in search of their mother, {@creature Ashtyrranthor|WDMM}.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The hoard consists of 249,280 cp, 121,472 sp, 11,302 ep, 6,025 gp, 200 pp, two ambers (100 gp each), four coral branches (250 gp each), two spinels (100 gp each), three bloodstones (50 gp each), five hematites (10 gp each), an old painting of a dwarf miner (25 gp), and a bear mask made of jade (250 gp).

entries.name: 13. Jerath's Quarters
entries: Characters who heard the strumming lute in area 12f can follow the music to this chamber, which contains the following:
{@b Jeath}. Jerath, a {@condition blinded} {@creature githyanki knight} with no eyes or armor (AC 12), sits in a chair strumming a lute. His greatsword leans against a wall within easy reach.
{@b Furnishings}. A lavish wood-framed bed stands near the wall across from four 2-foot-high, 6-inch-wide window slits. By peering through the slits, one can see the starry void of space beyond.

Jerath lost his eyes in a battle against the ulitharid on display in {@area area 9|842|x}. He saved {@creature Ashtyrranthor|WDMM}'s life when she was a wyrmling, and she has cared for him since his injury. Characters who speak Gith and succeed on a DC 12 Charisma ({@skill Deception}) check can convince Jerath that they are githyanki. Jerath shares any information he knows with fellow githyanki, including the layout of Stardock, the unhappiness of the young dragon Infernexus, and {@creature Al'chaia|WDMM}'s cruelty.

If Jerath believes the characters are not githyanki, he tries to keep them in this area with conversation or a song. He knows that {@creature Ashtyrranthor|WDMM} crawls by the window slits once every 10 minutes to check on him. If she sees or smells intruders in Jerath's presence, she storms into {@area area 12f|857|x}, makes her way here, and dispatches them.

entries.name: 14. Infernexus's Quarters
entries: The unhappiest of {@creature Ashtyrranthor|WDMM}'s brood, a male {@creature young red dragon} named Infernexus, claims this chamber as his lair. The dragon sleeps across from the door underneath four 2-foot-high, 6-inch-wide window slits that peer into the starry void.

{@creature Ashtyrranthor|WDMM}'s youngest child is miserable on Stardock. He is eager to leave the asteroid and begin life on his own, but his mother insists he help the githyanki. So he spends most of his time here, sleeping or darkly staring out into space.

If the characters do not attack him at once, Infernexus proposes a deal. He helps them achieve their goals in the asteroid if they promise to kill his mother and help him carve out a lair for himself in Undermountain. He's very particular and doesn't consider any lair other than the Twisted Caverns ({@adventure level 4|WDMM|4}) suitable. If a deal is struck, Infernexus becomes the characters' loyal companion for {@dice 1d10} days. But if they haven't gotten the dragon to the Twisted Caverns by then, he betrays them.

If the characters attack Infernexus or refuse his deal, he fights until reduced to 100 hit points or fewer. He then screams for his mother, who hears the call and arrives at the window slits {@dice 1d4 + 1} rounds later.

entries.name: 15. Githyanki Trainees
entries: Githyanki children are brought to the crèche to grow, train, and study in these connected caverns.

entries.name: 15a. Training Area
entries: If the characters make any loud noise here, the {@creature githyanki knight} in area 15b investigates. This cavern has the following features:
{@b Straw Dummies}. Straw dummies crafted to resemble mind flayers stand near the center of the chamber.
{@b Apparatus}. A large climbing apparatus made of black steel is mounted to one wall.
{@b Inscriptions}. Gith inscriptions cover the remaining walls. (They recount crimes perpetrated by the githzerai and the mind flayers against the githyanki.)
The straw dummies are used for combat practice. Each is a Medium object with AC 10, 10 hit points, immunity to poison and psychic damage, and vulnerability to fire damage.

entries.name: 15b. Tutor's Quarters
entries: A male {@creature githyanki knight} named Kaaltav dwells in this area. If not already alerted, the knight sleeps in a canopied four-poster and wakes at any loud noise. If he is alerted, the knight moves to area 15a to keep intruders from harming the children in area 15c.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Kaaltav's plate armor is set with six zircons (50 gp each) and six violet garnets (100 gp each).

entries.name: 15c. Githyanki Quarters
entries: Twenty githyanki children (noncombatants) sleep in small stone-framed beds in this room. Any movement in the room wakes {@dice 1d6} of them, who see the characters and shout out in alarm. The githyanki knight in area 15b arrives 1 round later as the other young awake. While the knight fights the characters, the githyanki young run throughout the crèche and raise the alarm.

entries.name: 16. Nursery
entries: Infant githyanki are brought to the crèche shortly after birth and raised in this nursery until they are old enough to undertake their training.

entries.name: 16a. Sleeping Area

entries: {@b Children}. Forty githyanki infants (noncombatants) sleep in crystal cradles arranged in five rows of eight.
{@b Window Slits}. Four 2-foot-long, 6-inch-wide window slits reveal the starry void of space beyond.

A creature moving through this chamber must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) check to avoid waking the sleeping infants. On a failed check, or if any loud noise occurs in this area, the infant githyanki wake and begin to cry. Both githyanki knights in area 16b investigate quickly.

{@creature Ashtyrranthor|WDMM} crawls by the window slits once every 10 minutes to check on the area. If she sees intruders here but the infant githyanki appear safe, she holds off attacking for fear of harming them. As soon as the intruders move into another area of Stardock, the dragon uses her magic or her burrowing speed to enter the asteroid and attack them.

entries.name: 16b. Nursery Guardians
entries: Two {@creature Githyanki Knight||githyanki knights}, a male named Ir'rigo and a female named Kritinaya, sleep in wooden beds against the walls. Any loud noise wakes the knights, who fight to the death against intruders.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Ir'rigo's plate armor is set with six orange carnelians (50 gp each) and six amethysts (100 gp each). Kritinaya's plate armor is set with eight lapis lazuli gemstones (50 gp each) and two blue spinels (500 gp each).

entries.name: 17. War Wizards
entries: Gish live and train in this section of Crèche K'liir.

entries.name: 17a. Gish Study

entries: {@b Furnishings}. Six cushioned chairs form a circle around a brazier of purple fire at the center of the room.
{@b Gish}. A female {@creature githyanki gish|MTF} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) named Vheza sits in one chair, reading a tome.
If Vheza sees intruders, she flees to area 17b with her book and makes her stand there.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The book that Vheza is reading is written in Gith and titled {@i The Ascension of Vlaakith}. It chronicles Vlaakith the Lich-Queen's rise to power in githyanki society and postulates that her absolute rulership would have been impossible had she not mastered arcane magic. The book also discusses the importance of wizardry as a githyanki tool for defeating their enemies and conquering the multiverse. The tome is worth 50 gp.
{@b Beds}. Six beds framed in white metal stand in a row down the center of the rough-walled room.

{@b Gish}. Two female {@creature githyanki gish|MTF} (see {@adventure appendix A|WDMM|25}) named Evir and Hraznin sit on beds and debate the finer points of magic. Each gish uses a crystal orb as an arcane focus and fights to the death.
{@b Window Slits}. Four 2-foot-long, 6-inch-wide window slits offer views of stars, the planet Toril, and the occasional spectacular sunrise.

entries.name: 17c. Arcane Training Ground
entries: The scorched remains of straw dummies crafted to resemble illithids are scattered around this rough-walled octagonal room. Burn marks from spell training cover the walls, floor, and ceiling.

entries.name: 18. Library
entries: The githyanki keep a modest library of books and maps on shelves carved into the asteroid's rock walls. These shelves run from the floor to the 15-foot-high ceiling of each chamber. Most githyanki use {@spell mage hand} to reach higher shelves, but a character can climb a shelf with a successful DC 12 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

entries.name: 18a. Book Collections
entries: The walls of this cavern and the two columns that support the roof are lined with books. All the volumes here are in Gith and concern the githyanki's history battling illithids and githzerai (see the "Gith" entry in the {@book Monster Manual|MM}).

entries.name: 18b. Map Room
entries: The shelves along the walls of this cavern are piled high with leather and bone tubes holding maps of planar locations and small, unnamed dungeons. A character who searches through the maps for 1 hour and succeeds on a DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check discovers a recently updated map of Stardock, though none of the asteroid's rooms are labeled.

entries.name: 18c. Reading Room
entries: Two cushioned chairs in this rough-walled room face 2-foot-long, 6-inch-wide window slits through which can be seen the void of space.

entries.name: 19. Warehouse
entries: Food, water, and other supplies for the inhabitants of the crèche are stored here.

entries.name: 19a. Loading Dock

entries: {@b Warriors}. Four {@creature Githyanki Warrior||githyanki warriors} are organizing crates and setting aside food for the kitchen. They attack in response to any threat or suspicious activity. If two githyanki fall, the survivors retreat to {@area area 21|87a|x}.
{@b Containers}. Stacked about the room are forty crates filled with nonperishable food and forty barrels of fresh water.
{@b Beams}. Two thick wooden beams lean against the wall between sets of double doors.

The food crates are each 2 feet on a side and weigh 50 pounds. The water barrels are 4 feet tall and weigh 500 pounds each. As an action, a creature can attempt a DC 22 Strength check to push over a stack of crates or barrels. A successful check triggers a domino effect, causing all the stacks to fall. Each creature on the floor of the room when the stacks topple must succeed on a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw or take 11 ({@dice 2d10}) bludgeoning damage and be knocked {@condition prone}.

The beams can be used to bar the double doors from the inside—a defensive measure in case the asteroid is attacked by spacefaring creatures. Each beam is 8 feet long and weighs 250 pounds. Once the double doors are barred shut, only a siege engine or a creature that has the Siege Monster trait can force them open.

entries.name: 19b. Cold Storage
entries: This area extends under area 18b, as indicated on the map. A magic ward keeps the temperature in this area at 10 degrees Fahrenheit. Characters who stay in this area for more than 1 hour suffer the effects of {@hazard extreme cold} (see {@book chapter 5|DMG|5|Weather} of the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|DMG}).
The githyanki keep twelve crates here, filled with fresh produce and meat and stacked in two rows of six. Each crate is 2 feet on a side and weighs 50 pounds.

The foodstuffs come from distant worlds and are unfamiliar to most of Toril's population.
